title: avoid publicity paul hollywood ask oscar winning judi dench
story: All the drama in his le — the latest being dumped by girlfriend Summer Monteys-Fullam after asking her to sign a laughably self-important “gagging order” — is entirely of his own making.Yet, in an Instagram post richer than triple chocolate mousse, he seemingly blames her for the media attention they attract. He also adds that: “I prefer a quiet le away from the day job.” And the band played Believe It If You Like.To recap: Paul is a master baker who caught a lucky break after being booked to appear on what became TV juggernaut The Great British Bake Off.Back then he was happily married to we Alex and, outside of an occasional media interview to plug the show, his home le never made the headlines.A bit of work and no play made Paul a dull boy when it came to clickbait. Then he had a fling with fellow TV chef Marcela Valladolid and all hell broke loose.Sex sells. It always has. So does scandal, and cheating on your we with a younger woman fits firmly into both categories.When the fling ended, the admirably forgiving Alex took Paul back, but the marriage faltered again and he took up with a -year-old barmaid with a fondness for miniskirts and crop tops.What’s not to love for the hundreds of “paparazzo”who make a living from how many times their photo gets viewed online It’s not rocket science, is it  Earlier this year I spotted Judi Dench out supermarket shopping.Yes, that Judi Dench. Dame of the British Empire. Oscar winner. Recipient of more awards than Mr Hollywood’s had hot buns.And favoured guest of chatshow host Graham Norton. But there she was, browsing the aisles and totally unbothered by anyone.Why  Well, firstly, she wasn’t wilfully drawing attention to herself by radiating self-importance. And secondly, while she’s paid to be dramatic on screen, her le outside of it is anything but.Meaning that, in everyday le, her showbiz currency — the aforementioned “clickbait” — is, depending on how you view such things, blissfully low.But , say, she decided to dump her conservationist partner David Mills for a young barman from her local pub, a photo of her low-key shopping trip would be front-page news. Simple really.Aside from the marvellous Ms Dench, there are oodles of A- listers who live non-famous lives, popping to the supermarket or going for a low-key dinner — for example, not The Ivy et al — with loved ones.Occasionally, they might be spotted and photographed, but they just keep their head down and ignore it, accepting that it’s a small price to pay for the myriad other benefits fame brings.NDAsare now commonly used by celebrities to ensure the silence of, say, a nanny who will be privy to what happens behind closed doors — and that’s perhaps understandable.But asking a lover to sign on the dotted line when you’ve already been together two years is saying, in so many words: “I don’t trust you, but I want to carry on sleeping with you.”Who can blame Summer for telling him to stick it where the sun don’t shine Famous US basketball coach and mentor, John Wooden , once said: “Talent is God given Be humble. Fame is man-given Be grateful. Conceit is self-given Be careful.”Wise words that Mr Hollywoodwould do well to heed.WHATEVER you think of Boris Johnson’s politics, it can’t be denied that he’s working his King Ashurbanipal socks offas our new PM.Hospitals, factories, flood-hit towns – you name it, he’s popping up there to put a smile on everyone’s face and reassure them that everything is under control.He’s the frontman while the rest of the bandare putting in the hours at the studio, hopefully producing the hits. Time will tell.But suffice to say, he’s already shaping up to be the UK’s cheerleader – a feat the more reserved and aloof Theresa May never quite managed.WHEN asked about children, Prince Harry replied that he and we Meghan might have “two, maximum”.Fair enough, I thought. After all, she’s  now and,she’s lucky, Mother Nature might let her conceive one more before her womb shuts shop.But no, it seems the royal couple’s decision is to do with population growth, despite experts saying that, globally, the birthrate is shrinking and the real issue is how long we’re all living.So unless he’s planning to pack Granny off to Dignitas, there’s not much he can do about it. But I digress.Regarding royal babies and, in particular, Harry and Meghan’s sensitivity around their firstborn’s privacy, perhaps they should copy his cousin Zara.She and husband Mike Tindall have two daughters, Mia, five, and Lena, one. There’s no showboating or churlishness, they just give their daughters as normal a le as possible via picnics, getting muddy, painting faces and rough and tumble – as seen in thisdelightful photo of mischievous Mia hitching a ride on Dad’s back.They occasionally get photographed, but clearly accept that it’s just one of those things and don’t let it bother them. A parenting template to be admired, whoever you are.THE author Alex Elle once said: “I am very cautious of people whose actions don’t match their words.”In which case, let’s hope she wasn’t invited to the recent Google Camp party in Sicily which,you’re one of the self-regarding A-listers in attendance, was a high-minded gathering to discuss the issue of climate change.Or to the rest of us – a boondoggle for entitled fools. How  to describe an event attended by  of some of the world’s richest people who arrived on eco-unfriendly private jets and luxury yachts Oh, the unacknowledged irony. Meanwhile, Leona Lewis and ious other celebrities, who advocate gun control, happily took a shilling or three to attend the Austria-based party of Gaston Glock – one of the world’s most famous gun makers.But back to Google Camp where – and I can’t quite believe I’m writing this – residents and hotel guests near the archaeological site of Selinunte were told by police to avoid looking out of their windows to protect the privacy of the invited A-listers dining al fresco.The same slebs, one assumes, who regularly virtue signal their moral credentials by advocating a world without borders, where everyone should be treated the same . . . yada yada. If hypocrisy was a movie, they’d all be winning Oscars.SCHOOLBOY Jay Hughes, , was talking to a friend outside a chicken shop in South London when a van pulled up and three men armed with machetes jumped out.His friend ran off and escaped but Jay stood in the shop doorway, where -year-old Nyron Jean-Baptiste stabbed him before boasting, “I got one”, and leaving the scene.Jean-Baptiste has now been jailed for “le” – whatever that means these days – while poor Jay’s distraught mother Cindy has been condemned to a letime of painful loss.Another devastated mother, Linda Burke-Monerville, spoke last month about sending her remaining children back to Nigeria for safety after losing three of her sons to violent crime in the UK.New Home Secretary Priti Patel said this week that she is resolutely focused on restoring law and order to our streets via extra police officers with greater powers.Talk is cheap – particularly when uttered by the majority of politicians. Action is what we need. And fast. Let’s hope she delivers before too many more young lives are snuffed out so brutally.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: whaley bridge residents can return to their homes after six nights away as dam is now safe
story: More than , residents had been evacuated from the Derbyshire town since Thursday as there were fears the dam wall could collapse following heavy rain, although a small number refused to leave their homes.The immediate danger posted to Whaley Bridge has now passed, police said.This is despite the fact the Met Office has issued a yellow weather warning covering much of England, including the Derbyshire town, on Friday and Saturday.Police said a safe water level at the reservoir had been reached after around  per cent of the reservoirs capacity had been pumped out.Derbyshire Police Deputy Chief Constable Rachel Swann said: The hard work and dedication to achieve this has been quite simply incredible.At the forefront of our thoughts are the communities affected by this incident who have been steadfast in the face of the peril that lay behind that dam wall.The danger posed by the millions of tonnes of water, which would have destroyed homes and livelihoods, could not be underestimated.She said work will now be carried out to ascertain the damage caused to the dam wall and what actions are required for the future.Prime Minister Boris Johnson tweeted: So pleased to hear that Whaley Bridge residents, who have shown such spirit and patience, are being allowed back into their homes.I want to thank the volunteers, emergency services, Armed Forces and all who responded with such professionalism and dedication.One resident who has ed, John Lomas, said: Its great to be back home. All the services guys have done an excellent job, Im very proud of them all.Another ing resident, Melissa Broxup, described the last few days as being an absolute nightmare.She added: Ive not been able to go anywhere and Whaley is so quiet. Everyone in Whaley has been amazing. Its not easy.Asked what it was like to be one of the first to be let back in, she said: Its great. I can finally get some sleep. I just cant wait to get back in my flat.Some residents had defied police warnings to leave their homes - even after being told they would face arrestthey did not evacuate.Cops had warned of a substantial threat to le had the dam wall collapsed.Malcolm Venton, , who stayed with partner Lorraine Ellis, , said: Its vindicated us really, I felt that we were never in much danger and thats proven to be the case.A police woman this morning asked meI was was one of those refusing to move and I sad yes.She said that I was foolish and told me well be the ones who have to retrieve your bodies.We were only just within the evacuation zone andanything were to happen, I had a bag packed and the car parked outside to drive literally  yards or so up the hill to the safe area.It didnt seem worth all the hassle of moving out to a temporary shelter, particularly as one of our border collies, Meg, is sick at the moment and is limping and so hardly able to move.All that upheaval wouldnt have been fair on her.On Tuesday an RAF Chinook was again drafted in to help the previously dropped bags of aggregate settle into place.RAF Regional Liaison Officer for the North West, Wing Commander Gary Lane, said: The work we have done is just finding its feet.When you put a load of aggregate down it needs stamping in, weve not been able to flatten that because it has just been dropped.He said about  military personnel had been drafted in to help with the dam.Deputy Chief Constable Swann insisted security measures were still in place in the area following reports of burglaries and prowlers.She said: We can assure you that security of the area continues. We are using drones regularly to patrol the area.The dam will eventually have to be rebuilt.The Environment Agency said there is still signicant work to be done to bring the dam to a condition where long term safety can be assured.

title: rollercoaster derail brazil theme park children
story: The Worm ride at a theme park in Cianorte collapsed with roughly a dozen passengers onboard, while horried onlookers watched the terrying ordeal unfold.The video, taken by an onlooker, shows the Worm ride start out at a slow pace, before gradually getting quicker after each turn.As the ride travels towards the cameras direction, it speeds up, before making a sharp turn.The turn then derails the ride, throwing riders off the structure completely.The ordeal took place in the evening of last Wednesday.It happened at a festival in the town of Cianorte, Brazil, on a ride they call Minhocão but Stateside is known as the Pinafari Wacky Worm.The video shows the coaster rounding the track and derailing, sending the children and adults on the ride hurtling off the track.Three people were left with injuries and had to be treated at a local hospital.Prior to the incident, the theme parks ride underwent three safety inspections by the Council, reported GMC.The ride was also inspected after the derailing, with the owner claiming the rides are inspected frequently and tested daily before the opening of the site.Officials are investigating what exactly caused the derailment.Last year, a rollercoaster in Florida sent two thrill-seekers plunging ft as dozens were left hanging in mid-air after the ride derailed above Daytona Beach boardwalk.Firefighters scrambled to Florida amusement park to rescue  people from the Sandblaster ride.Six were rushed to hospital after suffering from unknown injuries, and two remain in a critical condition.Local reports claim some passengers were trapped for up to  minutes after the rollercoaster suffered a mal.

title: girl seriously burned primark nail glue
story: Little Lilly Worsfold, , was engulfed in a toxic cloud after the p adhesive - marketed to children - made contact with the cotton-and-Lycra garment.Nursery manager Louise, , said: “I allowed Lilly to buy some pink plastic nails and a bottle of nail glue from Primark as a summer holiday treat.“She’s used them before - usually she sticks them on and they fall off a few days later.“But on this occasion she spilt a tiny amount of the glue on her leggings and they suddenly started smoking. I’ve never seen anything like it.“Lilly was screaming in agony. I pulled her leggings off as quickly as I could. They were red-hot and starting to stick to her skin.“I rushed her to hospital and they sent us to a specialist burns unit. Now they’re saying she may have to have skin grafts.“As a mother I feel partly responsible for letting her have the nails, but they’re clearly marketed to children and she bought them herself without any questions being asked.“Primark needs to take this product off the shelves immediately before another child is hurt - maybe even more seriously.”Louise, of Farnborough, Hants, added: “Lilly is a very responsible girl, I wouldn’t let her use nail glue otherwise.“I always thought the worst that could happen with nail glue was that you could temporarily stick your fingers together - not that it would ignite your clothing and cause chemical burns.“This is a terrible start to the summer holidays. Lilly can’t go swimming or to the beach and has to keep her legs elevated as much as possible. She’s also facing the prospect of surgery.“On top of that, she’s terried of starting a new secondary school in September with horrible scars all over her legs.”Lilly spent £ of her pocket money on a set of pink plastic nails and p on a bottle of brush-on nail glue from Primark on Saturday.Both bore the chain’s “P.S.” beauty brand marketed at girls and young women.Lilly started applying the nails in the back of the car on the way home. But after spilling a bit of the glue on her £ “Pink Soda” leggings from JD Sports, they started emitting noxious smoke.Her sister Poppy, eight, and three-year-old brother Hugo complained their eyes were stinging as the poisonous cloud filled the car.Louise pulled over immediately and removed Lilly’s leggings, swabbing the burned areas with wet tissues before driving to nearby St Peter’s Hospital, Chertsey.They assessed the injuries and referred Lilly to a specialist burns unit in East Grinstead, West Sussex.Doctors conducted tests which showed the burns were quite deep, and may require skin grafts.Louise and husband Peter, , complained to Primark and they asked them to send in the glue for testing.The cut-price chain apologised for the incident and said it would try to work out why the glue caused such a reaction. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: fit slashes dementia by half

story: In it, he speaks to gang members and community workers who are trying to stem the tide of bloodshed on Britain’s streets. He tells us what he discovered . . .It’s a Friday night and we are trying to hand in a machete and a samurai sword at a police station — but we are turned away.I’ve joined campaigner Faron Paul, who runs a one-man kne amnesty, offering shopping vouchers to peoplethey hand in their weapons to him.Faron, , came up with his unique way to try to reduce kne crime on the streets of North London, where he lives, after he was stabbed himself.People contact him on social media and arrange to drop off the blades. He collects up to  knives a day before handing them over to police.Faron, who dubs himself a “Daddy by day and a vigilante by night”, was given the two blades that day. Yet when we arrive at South Harrow police station, there’s a problem.There are no police officers there. And while the station did have a kne amnesty bin, it was rather unhelpfully taped shut. Evenit hadn’t been, the blades we had were far too big to fit.A duty public access officer we spoke to wasn’t in a position to take the weapons and told Faron to take them to Wembley police station.For me, this was a ludicrous suggestion.This was a Friday night and anything could have happened.It wasn’t until I stepped in and pointed out it would be safer for him to take the knives than for us to drive around with them that he was convinced.And it was the third police station we’d tried that evening. The first, Ilford, had a two-hour wait. The second, Pinner, was shut.Faron was a promising athlete — but as a teen his dream of becoming an Olympic medallist was snatched away from him after he was viciously stabbed in two separate attacks.He told me he contemplated revenge and only changed his mind because of the impact it would have had on his family.He should be commended for what he does. And while I wouldn’t recommend others to follow suit, I know he’s not the only person who feels compelled to take matters into their own hands in the face of the kne crime epidemic that is gripping the UK.Because for three years now our politicians have been so obsessed with Brexit and debating our future they have failed to spot that our future is happening now.Kne crime has surged to the highest levels since records began in .In England and Wales,  people lost their lives by a kne or sharp instrument in the year leading up to March , according to official figures.There has been a  per cent increase in the number of victims aged  to . That’s a massive hike in young people getting stabbed on our streets. And every day last year around three people aged ten to  were admitted to AE with kne wounds.Despite what people might think, it’s not just a problem in London. Kne crime is growing fastest outside the capital.We need to start getting the message across that it’s not just affecting inner-city kids in London, as tonight’s programme shows with a look at the problems in the North.These chilling statistics are what led me to investigate the UK’s kne crime epidemic for the penultimate episode of my latest ITV documentary series — because whatever is being done is not working. And we have to look at the reasons why our young people pick up a kne.During filming I spoke to one young man who viewed the side holster for his machete in the same way as a new pair of trainers — a fashion accessory.Gang members I spoke to all have one thing in common, revealing they were all excluded from mainstream school before having a chance to finish full-time education. They were all sent to pupil referral units.It’s been suggested that, because schools are under so much pressure from Ofsted to be high-achieving, they push out the troublesome children who could bring down the rest of the class.One of the young gang members said to me: “You tell meit makes sense to put a bunch of bad kids from one area that already have problems into an environment with other bad kids from another area. That doesn’t make sense.”Of course it doesn’t. It’s obvious when you think about it, isn’t it And while some of these pupil referral units succeed, many are seen as training academies for crime gangs.When our new Prime Minister Boris Johnson pledged to hire up to , police officers by this time next year, it was given a warm welcome.The recruitment drive begins next month, with the ambitious aim of having , officers in place within three years.It’s a good thing, don’t get me wrong. But how long will it take to train these officers And how long, once in place, will it take them to build trust in the community The young men I met told me the same thing time and time again: “Show me a better way.” Faron is a great example of how social media can be used for good. But I’ve seen first-hand how it plays a negative part in the rise of kne crime in this country and how easily name-calling online can result in the death of a young person.Not only has it taken away a le and has an impact on the victim’s family, it also has a massive impact on the perpetrator and their family.It’s cancelling out lives, essentially over name-calling on social media.During filming, most of the people I met felt like they were facing or fighting kne crime alone — from the young person carrying a kne for protection to someone in the local community having to take matters into their own hands because they feel there is no other option.Yesterday, counter terror chief Neil Basu said improved social mobility in the UK could do more to stop extremism than “policing and state security” combined.He added that policies which go towards better social mobility and more education are much more likely to drive down violence.And what he says about terrorism could just as well apply to kne crime.There is certainly no quick fix to this problem. We need to stop young people picking up knives, and this will involve giving them options rather than just excluding them. We need to look at the part played by social media in the escalation of violence.We need to look at the connection between poverty levels and kne crime and to send the message that carrying a kne is not cool or fashionable.And, of course, we need more police officers who have the trust of the communities they police.And, more importantly, government needs to convince the people living on the front line of kne crime that there is genuine help out there. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no need to ditch traditional puds
story: More than a third of young diners have never eaten a spotted dick and a quarter have never had a slice of flan, according to a study.What’s more, a fth of Brits aged  to  have never tried Eton mess, banoffee pie or rhubarb crumble — and one in six last ate jelly and ice cream TEN years ago.Traditional puds celebrate seasonal ingredients and are a pleasure to make. In winter there is nothing quite as satisfying as a steaming jam roly-poly with custard.Trle, my favourite, dates back  years. The word originally meant a light dessert, literally “a nothing”.But many desserts are disappearing from our menus.It’s not just the unfortunate overtones of roly–poly and spotted dick that are putting people off.Today, sugar, eggs, dairy and bread are out of fashion. People are opting for healthier desserts. Trendy cafes serve raw, dairy-free cakes.But I have to say “healthy dessert” is possibly the most disappointing combination of two words in the entire English language.Perhaps millennials are scared about the calories from eating out because of the growing pressure to look good on social media. If that’s the case, it’s very sad. Everything in moderation is fine.Processed food with lots of mysterious ingredients and high levels of salt and sugar is a very recent contrivance.Our grandparents ate ­simple, home-cooked meals made from fresh ingredients, and food was comparatively expensive, so people tended to eat smaller portions.Eat sensibly. You can enjoy sugar just as you might enjoy the occasional glass of wine.My kids love baking and making cakes is a great way to introduce them to cooking.Millennials are eating more fresh fruit, which is good. But food isn’t medicine. It should be something we look forward to and enjoy.Something that, eaten in moderation, will leave us feeling fully satisfied. And there are not many things that can do that for under a fiver.Here, I celebrate my favourite traditional puddings . . . Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk holds the best cards brexit
story: We were warned about this before the referendum and have been told almost continuously for the past three years a British recession is just around the corner. But things aren’t quite working out that way.While the UK economy is far from booming, it is holding up much better than those in the Eurozone. Figures released yesterday show Germany’s manufacturing sector contracted by . per cent in July and is now a shocking . per cent smaller than it was a year ago.Given the importance of manufacturing to the German economy, it is likely the whole economy is now heading for recession — a fate the country only narrowly avoided at the end of last year.In Italy, too, economic growth has ground to a halt again — after the country only just hauled itself out of last year’s recession. In France, growth in the past three months fell to . per cent.By contrast, our economy looks relatively perky, with growth of . per cent in the three months to May. Figures released on Monday showed a rebound in confidence in the dominant services sector.Of the large Eurozone countries, only Spain is currently outgrowing us — but Spain is still recovering after a very deep recession from which it emerged in . In common with Italy, the Spanish economy is still smaller than it was before the - banking crisis.Not that you will hear any of this from Remainers. Every time a car factory is earmarked for closure or a steelworks runs into problems, we hear no end of people saying, “We told you so”.All bad news in the UK economy is automatically attributed to Brexit — on the BBC, especially. What we don’t hear is that manufacturing industries, especially cars and steel, are suffering the same problems across Europe.Germany’s car industry is still reeling from the scandal of Volkswagen cheating in emissions tests by installing software to detect when a car was in test mode.On top of that comes the proposed switch from petrol and diesel to electric cars. Many motorists — myself included — have put off buying new vehicles because we don’t know what to get.We have been told new petrol and diesel cars will be banned from  and worry they might be taxed out of existence well before then. Yet electric cars are still prohibitively expensive and can’t travel nearly far enough between charges.As for the steel industry, all across Europe it is struggling to compete with cheap competition from China — especially since the trade war with the US forced Chinese exporters to search for new markets away from America.Of course,we end up with a No-Deal Brexit and tarfs are imposed on imports and exports between Britain and the EU, it will cause some disruption to trade. But it is wrong to assume Britain will come off worse. In truth, EU exporters have more to lose. Britain runs a huge trade deficit with the EU.In  we exported £billion worth of goods and services to other EU countries and imported £billion from them — a trade gap of £billion. Moreover, EU exports to Britain are concentrated in products that attract relatively high tarfs.Cars, for example, attract an EU import tarf of ten per cent. If Britain chooses to impose that levy in reverse after Brexit, it will cause further mayhem in the German car industry.We also have a high deficit in food — which under EU rules attracts average tarfs of  per cent. For dairy products, the average EU import tarf is  per cent. If our Government decides to impose this on imports from the EU, it will mean the end of quite a few French cheese producers.Of course, the EU can avoid damaging these export industries by agreeing to a trade deal with the UK — one that doesn’t include the hated Irish backstop.Nearly half of Irish food exports go to the UK. Irish exports to other EU countries would be deeply affected as so many rely on UK roads. If there are delays at ports, traffic between Ireland and the Continent will suffer twice over — once crossing the Irish Sea then crossing the English Channel.EU leaders want to punish Britain for voting to leave their sacred project. They fear thatBritain is seen to do well, other countries will want to leave. But playing hardball with Britain will do deep harm to their own export industries.Does German chancellor Angela Merkel want to suffer the wrath of her country’s car makers  Does French president Emmanuel Macron wish to anger winemakers already struggling with an economic downturn at home A hard Brexit could cost Denmark as much as one per cent in lost gross domestic product. Their former economy minister Simon Emil Ammitzboll calls Brexit “the most visible threat to the Danish economy”.Holland and Belgium calculate similar falls will hit their economies, with the Dutch losing ten billion euros by . In Spain, wages for unskilled youths are lower than they were in the late s. Youth unemployment is a huge problem. Even qualied youths face a lower annual salary than their counterparts a decade ago.It won’t take much. Just remove the backstop — really just an underhand way of trying to keep Britain in the straitjacket of EU regulations and trade barriers — and some kind of withdrawal agreement would almost certainly make it through the Commons.If not, then yes, British industry will suffer in some ways from No Deal. But the Eurozone economies already lagging behind will take the bigger hit.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris playing hardball eu from outset
story: First, he’s making the threat of No Deal serious. With Theresa May, it never was. Brussels knew she didn’t even want to leave, never mind with No Deal.And whenever No Deal was threatened there would always be some helpful soul in her Cabinet to say . . . “That will never happen.”  People such as the treacherous Philip Hammond.Not any more. Second, he’s shaking up the civil service a bit.  It was civil servants who did most of the negotiating — and they are all wildly pro Remain.But with Boris’s adviser Dominic Cummings wielding the stick they might just be a little more amenable than before.Third — he’s realised that the bloody Northern Ireland backstop was never anywhere near so serious an impediment as the Remainersclaimed.And fourth, and maybe most importantly, he’s leading the country with a sense of optimism and chutzpah.Of course it’s Boris, so he may well do something totally bonkers and wreck the process. But so far he’s got everything right.He hasn’t got long to sort out a deal, the days are counting down. But my guess is that he WILL get one.The EU likes to talk a hard game but it usually budges in the end. It is desperate to avoid No Deal.Andit doesn’t budge — fine. A bumpy road for a few weeks and we’ll be OK, better off than ever. And free. The big threat to Brexit is not the EU — it’s our Parliament, once again.The Labour Party has ditched all semblance of principle and is now for a second referendum.Worse, Boris has a majority of only one. That’s not his fault — blame Theresa May for calling an election two years ago.It looks to me thatMagic Grandpa Jeremy Corbyn calls a vote of no confidence, he will probably win.Labour is already cosying up to the Scottish Nationalists and saying they wouldn’t mind a second referendum on independence.There is now nothing Labour wouldn’t do to gain power. Destroy the union and scupper Brexit — Magic Grandpa doesn’t care.Butthis whole thing ends with Labour des- troying Brexit, the party will never be trusted again.Oh sure, it will still get the votes from the metropolitan, middle-class lefties. But its working-class base will desert it, for good.So the message for Magic Grandpa is very clear. Win your vote of confidence, lose your voters. He’s not the brightest of men, but I do hope he grasps this.And Boris  Keep straight ahead. Play as hardball as possible with Brussels, knowing they want a deal. Strike as many deals with the likes of the USA and Canada as possible.And remind Brussels thatwe walk away without a deal, they don’t get a single penny from us. That should help to concentrate their minds for a while.This has been revealed in a new report by researchers with too much time on their hands. What these men want, I think, is the best of both worlds.I used to have a girlfriend who spent all day long sitting on the roof of the shed. Then she’d dart out into the road after a thrush. She was great.Had a little bell around her neck. And did her business in a small tray by the back door.A WOMAN in East London said nasty things to someone taking part in a gay Pride march. She was wearing a niqab, so the lefties didn’t get too cross.Still, it is at last beginning to dawn on the woke liberals that the more fervently Muslim a person may be, the less likely it is that he or she will take kindly to people who have a knack for interior design and enjoy watching Mamma Mia!.This has put them in a bit of a quandary. Much as have those largely Muslim protests outside schools in the Midlands which insist on teaching kids how wonderful gay relationships might be.The same sort of quandary that affects feminists, who are not entirely convinced that a ft chap with a todger and a beard who wishes to be called “Loretta” in the name of gender freedom actually is a woman.This is the thing with identity politics, protected characteristics and so on. Tug gently on one of its threads and the whole thing begins to unravel like a pink mohair jumper knitted by an imbecile. HERE’S some consol­ation for you cricket fans, in despair at our Ashes defeat. Steve Smith, the man who did most of the damage, is at least HALF English.He’s got an English mum and has dual nationality.He used to play cricket for a team in Sevenoaks, in Kent.So what we should do is ide his run total down the middle – we get half, the Aussies get half. That means we won the first Test. Fair dinkum Sometimes I think that one day I’ll be the only person left in the country paying tax.And I’ll get rung up by the Inland Revenue. “Sorry, Liddle, we need to fire off a few missiles to scare the Iranians. We’ll take it out of your next payment.”Thing is,people aren’t paying tax, or aren’t married to someone paying tax, should they have the vote THE way to pose for your Instagram shots this summer is to stand with your elbows in the air.Here is someone doing exactly that.And so everywhere you go this August, you will find young women doing a passable imitation of a cormorant.Those scented pine-tree things could obscure your view of oncoming traffic, apparently.Have to say, I wouldn’t mindthey were banned altogether. Especially that really sickly one that’s supposed to smell of coconut.Here’s a tip, mini-cab drivers. If you want your car to smell nice for passengers, maybe take a shower once in a while HANGING an air freshener from your car rear-view mirror could land you a fine.APPARENTLY,you stare hard at a seagull in a menacing fashion it will be too scared to nick your packet of chips.This is the new advice from the experts. I’ve known it all along. Stare hard at the bird asit’s just spilt your pint, or tried to chat up your girlfriend.And also add in a bit of abuse and threats for good measure. “You f***ing want some, you yellow-beaked t***er “I’ll cut you open like a tin of peaches, Sunshine.” Always works, until the Old Bill turn up. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyn labour unfit government
story: But Labour are still lumbered with their dismal, discredited chief.Even as Jeremy Corbyn sinks deeper in the mire of unpopularity, his party makes no real attempt to dump him.Instead of taking action, Corbyn’s detractors just carp and criticise from the sidelines.Last week’s poor result in the Brecon and Radnorshire by-election, where the Labour candidate gained just five per cent of the vote, led to a new wave of condemnation.Former Northern Ireland Secretary Lord Hain said that Labours performance at Brecon had been truly dreadful, yet our current leadership carries on regardless towards disaster.Even more savage was another former Cabinet Minister Alan Johnson, one of the most respected Labour moderates, who said that practically anyone would be better in the job.Jeremy Corbyn is not just pious and sanctimonious, he’s useless at leading, which is why he has people around him to do his shoelaces and pull his strings, claimed Johnson.MORE IN COMMENT" px, px" JANE MOORE You CAN avoid all publicity, Paul Hollywood — just ask Oscar-winning Judi Dench As a former Labour activist who spent a decade working alongside Corbyn in his Islington North constituency, I agree with everything Johnson says.Having observed him at close quarters during the years when he was a backbench rebel, I now find the idea of Corbyn as Prime Minister both laughable and terrying.Profoundly unfit for the highest office, he is a toxic ideological extremist without a clue about how to govern Britain.Having poisoned his own party, he would wreck our country toohe came near to power.But what makes me despair is the timidity of sensible Labour folk, who regard Corbyn with contempt yet are still willing to march under his banner.They proclaim that they think he is a disaster, but they allow him to remain in place.This pathetic ineffectuality was captured by Yvette Cooper, widely regarded as possible alternative leader, who bleated to the BBC at the weekend that there is a real concern we don’t look like enough of a broad church at the moment.What a gross understatement.In fact, the Labour Party is in the grip of hardline, quasi-Marxist, anti-Semitic personality cult.But apart from wringing their hands, the likes of Ms Cooper do nothing about it.If Labour is to have a future, the moderates have to get off their knees and start to challenge Corbyn properly.They should be inspired by the words of the great former leader Hugh Gaitskell, a passionate centrist, who famously told the  conference — where the left had prevailed — that he would fight, fight and fight again to bring back sanity and honesty and dignity to the party I love.The moderates need that kind of resolution today, but they show precious little sign of it.They are not only cowardly, but also hypocritical.They send their angry tweets and whine to the broadcasters, but, by campaigning for Labour, they are still working for Corbyn to be Prime Minister.If, as appears likely, a General Election is called soon, the so-called moderates will all be out canvassing in their constituencies for theof a Corbyn-led Government.That reality makes all their denunciations of him completely meaningless.Effectively, the moderates are Corbyn enablers and agents of his extremism.Rather than serve as doormats, they should take a lesson from the Tories, who have long been ruthless about dumping their leaders.Neville Chamberlain, Anthony Eden, Ted Heath, Iain Duncan-Smith, and even Margaret Thatcher were all clinically dispatched once they were deemed to be ineffective or unpopular.The same ruthlessness with personnel could be seen in the way Boris Johnson reconstructed his Cabinet last month as he sacked  ministers in his night of the blond knives, including even the Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt.In contrast, Labour has always been pathetically soft about butchery.In the whole of the party’s -year history, only one leader has ever been forced out against his will and that, ironically, was Tony Blair, by far Labour’s greatest election winner.All the rest chose when to go, even the poor ones like Neil Kinnock, Michael Foot and the s pacist George Lansbury.Today, there are plenty of steps that the moderates could take to crank up the pressure on Corbyn.They could push for another vote of no confidence in him. They could resign the Labour whip in the Commons. They could boycott his appearances at Prime Ministers Questions and other statements.But, as Labour slides towards catastrophe, they have done none of this.What explains their inaction  Part of the answer is fear of the Corbyn machine, especially his supporters’ powerful pressure group Momentum, which is notorious for its intolerance.In fact, though there has been a recent decline in Labour membership, Corbyn backers still make the majority of activists.Any Labour MP who speaks out against Corbyn therefore risks deselection. For the sake of their Parliamentary careers, most of them keep quiet.But there are also deeper factors at work.One is mainstream Labour’s horror at any supposed betrayal of the socialist cause.This is partly because Labour is such a tribal movement, as shown in the ferocious anger generated in  by Ramsay MacDonald’s decision to break with the party by forming a National Government with the despised Tories.Since then treachery is regarded as the greatest sin, far worse than incompetence or unpopularity.This trait particularly insulates Corbyn, who, for all his spectacular failings, is still regarded by the majority of the membership as an authentic socialist.There is also a deep streak of sentimentality in Labour, which stems from the party’s origins in the trade union movement.In this mindset of supposed compassion, sacking people is what the bosses do, not the workers.When the nondescript Clement Attlee was surprisingly elected Labour leader in , supporters of his rival Herbert Morrison tried to comfort him by saying Attlee’s spell at the top would be short-lived.Morrison was having none of it.The party, he said, was sentimental and having once made a man leader, would stick to him.He was right. Attlee was still in post  years later.Sentimentality explains why so many anti-leadership plots are botched.I saw this for myself working as a Labour researcher at Westminster in the late s and early s, when there were hidden manoeuvres against Kinnock.But they all came to nothing because the plotters lacked the determination to finish the job.The same was true during Gordon Brown’s woeful premiership, when conspirators abandoned the battle when the moment came to strike.More interested in dogma than office, the Labour party lacks the unsparing instinct for power that infuses the Tories, which helps to explain why the Conservatives have been in Government for twice as long. Since  , the Tories have been in office for  years and Labour for just .The absence of hard ambition means that socialists are willing to put up with a dud like Corbyn, while they mouth their slogans and wave the red flag.The wilderness is their ideological comfort zone – and Corbyn will ensure they remain there.

I am certainly not fatalistic about that.”But DUP Brexit spokesman Sammy Wilson urged Boris to channel the spirit of Margaret Thatcher in responding to Mr Varadkar’s suggestions.“Revoking Article  means overturning the referendum result, accepting the current Withdrawal Agreement means you split up the UK, and the extension simply kicks the issue down the road until a new government comes in, which is what the EU would love to happen.“None of them are realistic in any way, and the PM ought to do the same as Margaret Thatcher did and say ‘no, no, no’ to all of them.”

title: can parliament stop no deal
story: NewsCan Parliament stop a No Deal Brexit  Everything you need to know before October Heres an explanation of exactly what MPs can and cant do to stop No Deal Brexit from happeningShareByOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsThe House of Commons options are quite limited "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBoris Johnson has dramatically stepped up preparations for Britain crashing out of the EU without a deal. And as No Deal nears, and the government and the EU donapost resume meaningful negotiations, it now looks like Britain could crash out with on October . It means Britain would immediately leave the EU, including the single market and customs union, without a transition agreement or settlement for how the next stage of negotiations would go. Experts have warned that the dangers to food supplies, the economy and peace in Northern Ireland could be dramatic. So a lot of MPs have pledged to stop it happening. But can they  This is everything you need to know about Parliament stopping No Deal.    Can No Deal Brexit be stopped  While in theory it is possible, the reality is probably notthe Government is determined to see it delivered.The timetable is such that the only way Parliament could really stop a No Deal Brexit is to beat the government in a vote of No Confidence and then quickly cobble together another government.But this isnapost likely to happen. Boris Johnson doesnapost need to do anything - because leaving on October  is enshrined in law, he just has to let it happen.For Parliament to stop it,  they need to show a level of coordination and unity of purpose not seen in politics since...well, ever. Politicians from opposition parties would need to agree on an agenda, and vote to deliver it, in a way which would likely punish most of the major participants at the ballot box. Why canapost Parliament just vote to reject leaving without a deal  Well theoretically it can, but it just wonapost do anything unless they use a very particular mechanism. MPs could try to take control of the timetable in the House of Commons and try and pass a law which would force the Government to block no deal. They have done this before - repealing standing order  which gives the Government business priority in the house - but requires a lot of effort and wrestling for the agenda for the House of Commons.  Procedurally this makes the Speaker John Bercow potentially a key figure - a decision on allowing MPs to vote on seizing the agenda would be his to make. But Boris Johnson hasnapost ruled out proroguing Parliament - basically suspending it - so that it couldnapost do something like this evenMPs have muddied the water by voting to make Parliament sit some days in October. One option under consideration is for them to vote to delete or amend the date in the Withdrawal Act - but they would need to granted the time to do this.Couldnapost Parliament vote down Boris Johnsonaposs government Yes - but the timetable for stopping a No Deal Brexit on October  is incredibly tight without some dramatic activity. The No Confidence vote could be put down on September  by Jeremy Corbyn - but he hasnapost committed to it yet. If he did, Labour would need Tory backbenchers, like ex-Chancellor Philip Hammond, who have sworn to block No Deal to vote with them.This in itself would be a political feat, as convincing Conservative MPs to back a Labour motion of No Confidence would involve convincing them they werenapost just handing Mr Corbyn the keys to No.    But, evenJeremy Corbyn won his vote it doesnapost automatically lead to a general election.If nobody wins a confidence vote within two weeks, an election is automatically called, with Mr Johnson staying as caretaker PM and deciding on the date. Boris Johnson has  days to prove he holds the confidence of Parliament by winning another vote. In this time another MP could come forward and demonstrate that they had the confidence of MPs, and be invited to form a government of national unity. They then could delay leaving the EU again so that Britain could hold an election or referendum. But that level of cooperation would require MPs to work together in a way that hasnapost happened since WWII. It would also involve Jeremy Corbyn backing another person to be PM ahead of him, evenonly temporarily, as the Lib Dems - not to mention the Tory defectors - have said they wonapost put him in No. The party has already said it wonapost do this. Even more bizarrely there have been reports that Downing Street sources have suggested that the government could refuse to give up power anyway until after October  - crashing the UK into another constitutional crisis. How could The Queen be dragged into it  WellMr Johnson refused to quit then one Tory has said it could drag the Queen into the middle of the constitutional battle. Former attorney-general Dominic Grieve, a leading rebel, said the monarch could then be left with little choice but to sack himhe lost the confidence of Parliament but for whatever reason refused to go.  “The Queen is not a decorative extra... at the end of the day there are residual powers and responsibilities which lie with her. She might have to dispense with his services herself,” he said. Other constitutional experts have said The Queen would do everything possible to avoid becoming involved in any political battle the country finds itself in. So will we have an election before October   Unlikely but not impossible. This is the outcome Boris Johnsonaposs government is most determined to avoid. They want to make sure that any vote, which almost everybody said is going to happen, isn only held after we leave the EU.

story: NewsScientists made Chernobyls first homebrew vodka - and its radioactive-freeThe special grain spirit was made using crops on a farm around the damaged nuclear power plant and contaminated water from the zoneShareCommentsByTfany Lo:,  AUG NewsAtomik is the Chernobyls first consumer product made after the nuclear disaster "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA home-brew vodka has been produced within the exclusion zone  years after the deadly Chernobyl disaster. The team, the brainchild of Chernobyl Spirit Company who started the vodka project, said: Our idea then was [to use that rye grain] to make a spirit.   Askedthe spirit is safe to drink, Prof Smith explained to BBC : This is no more radioactive than any other vodka.Any chemist will tell you, when you distill something, impurities stay in the waste product. So we took rye that was slightly contaminated and water from the Chernobyl aquer and we distilled it. A radio-analytical laboratory test at Southampton University showed the content was aposbelow their limit of detectionapos, Prof Smith added.    He hopes the sale of the vodka could enable them to distribute most of the money to local communities and use the rest to reinvest in the business. The problem for most people who live there is they donapost have the proper diet, good health services, jobs or investment, he said. title: british man running sickening safaris
story: NewsSlaughter safaris sold by Brit: Ex-gamekeeper runs trips for rich to kill animalsEXCLUSIVE: Ex gamekeeper Derek Stocker’s ProStalk company specialises in trophy hunts to South Africa, Namibia and Zimbabwe killing baboons, monkeys, elephants, giraffes, and zebrasShareCommentsByNada FarhoudAdam Aspinall:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsEx gamekeeper Derek Stocker’s ProStalk company specialises in trophy hunts to South Africa, Namibia and Zimbabwe "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailGrinning Brits pose behind the body of defenceless animals shot dead on African ­trophy hunts, in images which will yet again sicken ­animal lovers. Emily Padfield and Les Baker are two of many UK visitors having souvenir pictures taken of them with their prizes, parts of which they can bring home. And a UK former gamekeeper is cashing in on the lust for blood by offering trips to slaughter threatened big game, under the “conservation” label. Derek Stocker’s ProStalk specialises in trophy hunts to South Africa, Namibia and Zimbabwe. They include killing baboons, monkeys, elephants, giraffes, and zebras on “adventures of a letime”.  And wealthy customers have bragged about their cruel exploits during the trips, which start at £, for five days. Hunters can add more animals to kill from a list of  species, including £, extra to shoot a giraffe, £, for a hippo or just £ for monkeys. Experts believe ProStalk is the last remaining major UK company ­organising big game hunts in Africa. Ms Padfield told how the trip was “truly the stuff dreams are made of”. But the Campaign to Ban Trophy ­Hunting’s Eduardo Goncalve branded the safaris “a festival of cruelty”.  He said of shooting monkeys: “Many of these animals live in close proximity to humans and are used to people. “It makes it even easier to shoot them. This is as cowardly as it is disgusting.” Eduardo added: “ProStalk boasts about the ‘thrill’ of killing animals. It may be a ‘holiday of a letime’ for a hunter, but it’s hell for the animal killed to satisfy their sick bloodlust. “Trophy hunting isn’t an ‘adventure’, it’s an abomination, and it needs to be abolished. The Government should implement an immediate moratorium on all hunting trophy hunting imports. “This is the last remaining major UK company organising big game hunts in Africa. It’s a stain on our country’s ­reputation as a nation of animal lovers. “It also has almost every iconic African animal on its hunting ‘menu’ including elephants, giraffes and zebras. All are listed as vulnerable by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature.  “Britain has some of the laxest laws on trophy hunting. We allow hunters to kill and bring home the heads and body parts of practically any animal, including some of the most endangered wildle. “Trophy hunting is a horror show, where cheap ­bounties are placed on the heads of animals for fun. Britain needs to show it plans to lead the way in ­abolishing this abomination by acting now before it’s too late.” The Mirror is calling for a ban on trophy hunting. ProStalk insists it plays a “pivotal role” in ­conservation. It says: “Hunting is such a controversial issue and ­unfortunately the ­uninformed public and animal rights activists are unaware of how much it contributes to conservation.” It also argues the growth of hunting since the s has placed a value on wildle and created a direct incentive to own, purchase, protect and conserve it. The firm says the ­establishment of private game ranches has helped some species recover in South Africa.

story: NewsCouple expecting twins devastated as both babies die within weeks of each otherRachael and Kirsty Hoyles, from Wales, have spoken about the tragedy in the hope of helping othersShareByMark Smith:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsRachaeland Kirsty Hoyles, from Cwmcarn, pictured with their baby sons Jude and Bayden "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA couple who were overjoyed to learn they were expecting twins have spoken of their heartbreak after both babies died weeks apart. Rachael and Kirsty Hoyles now want to help others through dficult times by sharing their story. They conceived following a successful sperm donation from a private clinic in Cardf, Wales Online reports . But tragedy was to follow when complications with both babies meant neither survived. We are heartbroken and would give anything to have our boys back, said Rachael, .    But we know thataposs not going to happen, so we decided to do the next best thing - help anyone  who has to go through this and try to make it more bearable. Rachael, who has been married to Kirsty since June , fell pregnant at the first attempt following a sperm insemination at a clinic in . We were allowed to choose a donor with similar characteristics to ours, she added. We decided to pick someone with similar eye and hair colour to Kirsty. After going through the procedure privately, they were then referred back to the Welsh NHS nine weeks into the pregnancy. However, at the -week scan at Ysbyty Ystrad Mynach it was discovered that one of the twins was very small. A rescan four weeks later revealed that the baby had a very rare birth defect called encephalocele.    It meant the babyaposs skull had not formed properly and had caused part of the brain to protrude out. Around one in , babies are struck down with it, but it remains a mystery as to what causes it. They [the hospital staff] just kept saying aposIaposm sorry, Iaposm sorryapos over and over again, said Rachael, from Cwmcarn, near Newport. We were told that the survival rate was not good. Just days later, their care was transferred to Bristol Childrenaposs Hospital where the diagnosis of encephalocele was officially confirmed. But while they were there, further scans picked up anomalies with the other twin. They said they couldnapost find the stomach, Rachael added. We were now at a crossroads as to whether to continue the pregnancy, but we decided to let it run its course to see what happened. We had many, many scans in Bristol and we were also being seen in Newport too. It was a really horrible time. Neither of us could work while this was happening. At every appointment we would just sit there crying in the waiting room. The second twin was found to have a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, known for short as CDH, which meant the babyaposs stomach had gone up into his chest, had crushed one of his lungs and pushed the heart to one side.  However, doctors said his le could be saved with an operationhe could hold on for a few weeks after birth. We were told he would survive in the womb as I was giving him all his nutrients through my placenta, but he would have to fight for himself for a while once he was born before they could put the stomach back where it should be. Rachael admitted that the complicated pregnancy really tested their marriage. We were very supportive of each other. We just wanted what was best as a family. We had a lot of friends reach out to us who had disabled babies about how hard, but rewarding it all was. At the -week mark, just before Christmas , Rachael and Kirsty were given the news they dreaded. The twin with encephalocele, who they went on to name Bayden, no longer had a heartbeat.  But to give the other twin the best chance of survival Rachael would need to try and get to full-term with both babies still inside her. We had my mum, Kirstyaposs mum and my stepdad all with us in the car [after the news] and we just sat and cried and cried, said Rachael. Nobody knew what to say to each other. It was horric. One of the risks of continuing to carry both babies in the womb was the chance of Rachaelaposs body could reject Bayden and go into early labour. But against the odds, she managed to get to  weeks and have a c-section at the University Hospital of Wales in Cardf on April , . Their son, Jude Hoyles was born alive and breathing. As soon as he was out they took him straight away to be intubated, so I wasnapost able to have skin-to-skin contact, Rachael said. I had to wait hours for the feeling to come back into my legs before I could be wheeled up to see him for the first time.

story: NewsDoctors advised girl, , to take Calpol before finding egg sized brain tumourEmily Keggan had been suffering from painful headaches in the lead up to being diagnosed with the stage  tumour which was pushing against her brainShareCommentsByJenny Foulds:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsEmily began suffering from headaches in June before eventually being diagnosed with a stage  brain tumour weeks later "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA seven-year-old girl was prescribed Calpol before doctors went on to find a aposKinder Egg sizedapos brain tumour. Emily Keggan had been suffering from painful headaches in the lead up to being diagnosed with the stage  tumour which was pushing against her brain. The youngsteraposs dad, Johny, , said the family, from West Dunbartonshire, Scotland, are trying to stay as positive as they can for their soldier little girl. He said: Emily started getting headaches around the end of May into June and they kept getting worse and worse. “It was going on for around three weeks and we took her to the doctors who said it was just migraines caused by stress at school and told us to give her Calpol. “But we knew it was much more serious. You know your own child and we weren’t happy with that. “We ended up taking her into the Queen Elizabeth University Hospital and she must have seen about nine or  doctors who checked her over.    “She eventually had a scan and that’s when the doctors took us into a room. “That was really distressing because we knew that meant there was something really wrong. “They diagnosed her with medulloblastoma cancer and told us they had found a tumour, which was about the size of the plastic tub you would get inside a Kinder egg. “It was pushing against her brain and they said they had to get it out straight away.” Emily was rushed into surgery and the tumour was removed. Her family are now facing an agonising wait as she undergoes months of radiotherapy and chemotherapy treatment in a bid to destroy any cancer cells which may still be in her body, reports the Daily Record . Johny continued: “She’s had tests on her spinal cord which haven’t shown any signs of cancer which is really good news. “It was a really aggressive tumour so they don’t know for sure whether there’s anything left which is why she’s having this intense treatment.    “The doctors said me and her mum were really ahead of the game in bringing her in. “They said they had never seen anyone get a diagnosis so quickly. More often, it’s left too long and spreads.” He went on to praise his “wee soldier” for showing so much strength and determination, adding: “She’s just finished her third week of radiotherapy and her hair is starting to fall out but you wouldn’t know anything was wrong when speaking to her. “She’s been a wee soldier going in for her treatment. She is only seven but she is so strong and brave – we are very proud of her.” Emily’s family have now launched a dream bid to fly the youngster and her brother Darren, , to Disney World in Florida once her ordeal is over. Her uncle Garry Keggan, who is Johny’s brother, has set up a Just Giving page, which has already raised more than £ towards the goal. Garry said: “Emily is going through absolute hell and I thought it would be a good idea to raise some money so they can go on a nice family holiday once this is over. Emily absolutely loves Disney and it would be a dream come true for her.

story: NewsMy le spiralled out of control when I was sold for sex aged  - by my own motherTyne Yates was friends with missing schoolgirl, Charlene Downes, and has revealed how she went off the rails in Channel  documentary, The Murder of Charlene DownesShareCommentsByAnn CusackJane LavenderAssistant Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  AUG NewsTynes own mother sold her for sex"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTyne Yates was just -years-old when her le spiralled out of control when she was sold for sex by her own mother. She was aposboughtapos for just £ to a middle-aged man in a notorious area of Blackpool as her drug addict mum watched. Tyne lts the sordid lid on how she was sucked into a le of child grooming, depravity and sleaze as part of a Channel  documentary looking into the disappearance of school girl, Charlene Downes. The now -year-old charts her own journey as she went off the rails - despite her middle-class background. Tyne said: “I went from being a kid looking for excitement to being passed around groups of men for sex.    As I got older, turned my back on my family, I got hooked on drugs and arrested countless times. I ended up a street prostitute, just like my mum. “It all started with bunking off school and hanging around in the town centre, just like Charlene Downes and a lot of other young girls. “It torments me knowing that I probably know her killers. “We were doing the same things with the same people at the same time. “When I look into the eyes of some of the men that prowl the streets preying on vulnerable young girls, I can’t help but wonderone of them was the last face that she ever saw.    “Something horrible happened to her and it could easily have been me.” The Murder of Charlene Downes is a three-part documentary, starting on Channel  tomorrow. It has unprecedented access to family, friends, suspects as well as police and legal experts. It tells the full story of Charlene’s disappearance and one of the biggest investigations in police history. Charlene vanished in November , aged .    Two local takeaway workers stood trial for Charlene’s murder in May  but were not convicted. The prosecution claimed that Charlene’s body had been cut up and minced into kebabs, her bones crushed into tile grouting. After a planned retrial was abandoned in , her parents began to give up hope of ever finding the truth. Tyne, a friend of Charlene’s, tells how she was marched down the notorious back alley just yards from the world-famous Golden Mile and in the shadow of Blackpool tower where her world changed forever. She said: “My mum was dferent to most of the other mums. She was a heroin addict and a working girl.    She really struggled with le but she was exciting to be around. It felt dangerous. I looked up to her. She was my mum and I loved her. “Then one day a man approached us in the street and asked her for sex. He said he wanted me and not her and that he’d pay a lot extra. I remember being led down the alley way by mum. “I still had my school unorm on and my bag. She told me everything would be ok, and it was all just part of le. I believed her.” Speaking from her one bedroomed tiny bedsit in Blackpool, Tyne wipes away the tears as she recounts the moment that changed her le forever.    She said: “Afterwards, she gave me my cut. A ten-pound note. I felt rich. It all seems so sad and pathetic. Bur that’s what happened to me.” “Not long after that, I met Charlene Downes.” The two schoolgirls came from very dferent backgrounds. Charlene was from a poor working-class family who had moved to the ‘Las Vegas’ of the north in search of a better le. Tyne tells how the two girls quickly became friends and would meet up and trawl around the takeaway and arcades looking for adventure but ended up selling themselves for fast food and pocket money. She said: “Charlene was fun, she was my friend. She was a year or so older than me, but not very streetwise.  I started to pass on to her all the tricks that my mum had shown me. She had a very dferent background to mine, but we had so much in common. “We had a regular route through the town that we would take, calling in at certain take away shops and arcades. She liked to dance for the drunks outside pubs. The Carousel Bar on the North Pier was a favourite place to steal drinks from the tables.” “When I heard that she had gone missing, I wasn’t too concerned at first.    She was wild and anything was possible. I honestly thought she would turn up sooner or later but the days turned into weeks then months and, here we are: sixteen years on and there’s still no sign of her. “I have had police swoop on me thinking I was Charlene a few times. title: letters week 24
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Further to your article #Three amigos clean up in Lochgilphead#, Friday May , I would like to add the lane behind Lochgilphead Bowling Club is often filled with fresh poo.I#m sick of coming over nearly every day and finding poo all over the lane. The lane floods, so between trying to dodge puddles, you land in dog dirt.I wish they would fix the path because a lot of people use it, some of them pensioners with or parents with prams.Celia MacFarlane, Lochgilphead.Sir,Seven out of ten people with diabetes feel overwhelmed by the demands of their condition and this signicantly affects their mental and physical health.That is why we are calling for new national standards for diabetes emotional and mental health support and to increase support available in Argyll to people living with diabetes.As part of Diabetes UK’s Diabetes Weekwe are urging people in Argyll to #SeeDiabetesDferently and back our campaign for national standards for diabetes mental health support and services.Our recently published research revealed the relentless nature of diabetes can impact people’s emotional well-being and mental health, ranging from day-to-day frustration and low mood, to specic psychological and mental health dficulties including clinical depression and anxiety.The findings, published in the report #Too often missing: Making emotional and psychological support routine in diabetes care#, show that diabetes is much more than a physical condition – and that emotional and psychological demands of living with diabetes should be recognised and support provided.Diabetes Scotland is urgently calling on the NHS to create national standards for diabetes emotional and mental health services. These should ensure everyone receives #joined up# care, that they are asked how they are feeling as part of every diabetes appointment and that a mental health professional with knowledge of diabetes is part of every diabetes care team.To sign our petition, go to diabetes.org.uk missingAngela Mitchell, National Director of Diabetes Scotland.Sir,I#m asking residents in the Highlands and Islands to give their views on Conservative proposals for tackling serious crime.In order to provide Scotland with an alternative to Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP in , we are keen to gain feedback from as many people to our policy proposals to make them as relevant as possible to the needs and aspirations of everyone in Scotland.Too many people in Scotland are affected by the behaviour of serious criminals. This needs to be properly addressed and my colleague Liam Kerr MSP, shadow Justice Secretary, has outlined key policy proposals in a member#s bill in the Scottish Parliament to tackle this scourge.It would give Scottish judges the power to impose whole le sentences to those convicted of the most serious violent and sexual crimes including the murder of a police officer.The courts would still have discretion to impose the appropriate sentence based on all the facts of each case, as they do in England and Wales where such a provision already exists.The proposed Whole Le CustodyBill will not mean the perpetrators of a particular crime will always receive a whole le sentence, but rather that the courts will have the power to impose one where there is sufficient justication.We have started the consultation and experts and members of the public are invited to register their views.Email me at donald.cameron.msp@parliament.scot or write to me at Donald Cameron MSP,  George Street, Oban, PA NT, with your views.MSP Donald Cameron, Highlands and Islands.Sir,The SNP has warned Scotland’s NHS is under threat from a Tory-Trump trade deal that could leave the Scottish Government without a veto over a post-Brexit deal that sells Scotland out.This stark warning follows the revelations from Donald Trump that in terms of trade deals, everything, including the NHS, would be on the table.At Prime Ministers Questions, SNP Deputy Westminster Leader Kirsty Blackman MP said Donald Trump and the Tories could not be trusted on the NHS and criticised the UK government for plotting to take powers away from the Scottish Parliament that would allow it to safeguard Scotland’s NHS.The threats to Scotland#s NHS are growing under the prospect of a hard-right Tory-Trump Brexit trade deal. Those threats could undermine the integrity and independence of our Scottish NHS.The UK Tories will block any potential veto by the Scottish Government over such a damaging deal.The SNP government will fight to the end to defend Scotland#s public services from this unprecedented Tory Brexit danger. Our NHS must remain in public hands. It is not, and should never be, up for sale.Scotland has been completely ignored throughout the Brexit process and Tory plans to grab powers from the Scottish Parliament will leave us even more exposed.It is clearer than ever that the only way to properly protect Scotland#s interests, and keep our NHS in public hands, is with the full powers of independence.MP Brendan O#Hara, Argyll and Bute.

title: shinty report 26 8 19
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowMowi PremiershipLochaber  Inveraray Inveraray saw off a Lochaber come-back to win their relegation battle at Spean Bridge.Inveraray started strongly and took the lead in the opening minute when Lewis MacNicol won the ball in midfield and found Garry MacPherson driving through the middle. He turned Duncan MacKinnon inside-out before flicking an inch-perfect ball to Fraser Watt on the left of the D and he slammed the ball high into the middle of the goal from  yards to make it -.Lochaber had their first shot on goal on six minutes when Ben Delaney found space on the left but his strike went wide of the left-hand post.Inveraray were showing good movement up front and they increased their advantage on nine minutes. The goal came from a corner and Garry MacPherson caught the Lochaber defence napping as he played the ball low from a wide area towards the front post where full centre Lewis MacNicol waltzed into the box and his first-time shot beat the helpless Callum MacDonald to make it -.Lochaber keeper MacDonald pulled off a great save on  minutes as he blocked Garry MacPherson’s fine drive from the left with his chest before clearing the ball to safety.Lochaber’s Ben Delaney and Stuart Callison tested Inveraray keeper Scott MacLachlan but it was the Winterton side who would add a third goal on  minutes. Again the goal came from Lewis MacNicol winning possession, this time deep in Lochaber territory, and he found the ever-alert Garry MacPherson whose defence-splitting pass picked out Fraser Watt running in unmarked through the heart of the Lochaber defence and he slotted the ball low past the keeper from close range.Lochaber were now up against it but, on  minutes, Conor Sweeney took a corner from the right, sending the ball into the danger-area. Stuart Callison found space to slam the ball goalwards and although Scott MacLachlan saved with his feet, he was unable to get the ball away and Ben Delaney was quick to react as he poked the ball over the line to make it - at the interval and give Lochaber hope.Lochaber started the second period with intent and Scott MacLachlan pulled off a great save to thwart Stuart Callison on  minutes.However, Lochaber’s never-say-die attitude got them right back into the match with just  minutes remaining. Lachlan Campbell played the ball across from the right and it came perfectly to the on-running Findlay MacDonald and his  yard shot from the left flew past the keeper to make it -, setting up a tense finishLochaber had a great chance to snatch a point on  minutes when referee John Angus Gillies awarded them a spot-hit, penalising keeper MacLachlan for a “kick” inside the D. Ben Delaney’s well-struck effort went straight down the middle and MacLachlan redeemed himself, saving superbly with his stick before clearing the ball for a corner.Inveraray saw out the rest of the game to claim two valuable points in what was a cleanly fought contest with no cards shown.The win sets Inveraray up for another crucial relegation battle this time at Kilmallie this coming Saturday.Caberfeidh  Kyles Athletic Kyles Athletic came from behind to beat Caberfeidh - in their pm throw up at Castle Leod.Caberfeidh have been on a bit of a scoring spree of late and they took the lead in the opening minute through Craig Morrison.It didn’t take Kyles long to level with Ross MacRae netting on  minutes and Colin MacDonald’s effort on  minutes meant they went into the break - ahead.Ross MacRae got his second on  minutes with Colin MacDonald doing like-wise with just  minutes remaining.Mowi South Division Inveraray  Kyles Athletic The Inveraray seconds and the Kyles Athletic seconds met in a match originally rearranged Thursday  July which was then put back  hours.Kane Kirkhope was playing in a more advanced role for Inveraray and he scored a well-taken goal in eight minutes after some impressive forward play.John MacKenzie was working hard in the middle of the park and he set up Inveraray’s second goal on  minutes. MacKenzie found Campbell Watt who let go a  yard strike which gave the Kyles keeper no chance.Inveraray sealed both points when Campbell Watt continued his good scoring run with his second goal of the game with  minutes remaining.

Players subscriptions covers pitch hire, insurance and other bits and bobs but it is the support from other organisations that allows us to be ambitious and grow not only the number of children participating but also development opportunities including bringing in professional coaches for development weekends which are free to local children.#
