title: Air ambulance responds to 140 local calls during second year in service
story: THE air ambulance service which this month is celebrating its second anniversary has responded to  emergency calls in the Newry, Mourne and Down Council area.Overall, the helicopter emergency service has responded to just over  emergency calls Province-wide.The service has a close local link as it was established as a result of a campaign led by the late Dr John Hinds, originally from Portaferry, who combined his two passions for motorbiking and working at the cutting edge of intensive care.From the motorcycling enthusiastrsquos early days in medical school, his focus was on working at the cutting edge of intensive care.He eventually combined these two passions to join the small team of flying doctors at road races who used their motorcycles to get to the scene of an incident within seconds.Dr Hinds was instrumental in leading the campaign for an air ambulance service to be introduced in Northern Ireland and had met with former Stormont Health Minister Simon Hamilton to discuss the issue.Sadly, he lost his le in a crash on the Skerries road racing course in Dublin in July , suffering multiple injuries which proved fatal.However, eight months after Dr Hindsrsquo death, funding was made available for an air ambulance which went into service in July , responding to more than  emergencies in its first year of operation.From its base near Lisburn, the air ambulance can reach any part of Northern Ireland in around  minutes, with its primary role is to deliver advanced care, benefitting those whose lives are at serious risk following signicant injury or trauma, by bringing urgent medical assistance directly to the patient at the scene.Air Ambulance Northern Irelandis the local charity that provides the Helicopter Emergency Medical Service, together with partners at the Northern Ireland Ambulance Service and operates seven days a week for  hours per day.Air ambulance head of fundraising, Kerry Anderson,said each time the helicopter takes off the charity is aware that someone is in great need.ldquoThanks to the generosity of people locally, the emergency medical service can offer the best chance of saving a le, she said.ldquoThe air ambulance is there for everyone and might one day save someonersquos le or that of a loved one. If we all do a little bit, wersquoll ensure the service is maintained for today, tomorrow and future generations.Earlier this year, local politicians agreed to take the lead in securing financial support for the air ambulance service and also make a monetary contribution to help meet the servicersquos poundm annual running costs.The Department of Health allocates around poundm in annual funding to help keep the helicopter service in the air with money used to finance the air ambulance crew, medicines and medical equipment. Charity funds, including public donations, sustains the aviation side of the operation.It was announced recently that as part of the ongoing consultation on reshaping stroke services, the Department has made a commitment to extend the partnership with Air Ambulance Northern Irelandto enable the helicopter emergency medical service to provide a secondary response to incidents, including strokes, by .Health officials have also confirmed that any changes to the existing arrangement would be subject to the completion of an appropriate business case and agreement with the air ambulance with regard to any funding implications..prettyPhoto

title: Charity Beer and Bubbles 5k run in Finnebrogue
story: M B McGRADY  Co Chartered Accountants is setting the pace this September with the launch of the Beer and Bubbles k run in a bid to raise money for Air Ambulance NI.Open to competitors of all ages and experiences, the race will take place on Thursday, September , at Finnebrogue Woods, nestled on the outskirts of Downpatrick.This is the first k race to take place at the idyllic venue, with the route mapped out so runners take in the stunning woodland and finish close to the lakeside, where they will be able to soak up the atmosphere while enjoying a glass of local beer or prosecco.The event follows on from last yearrsquos successful M B Grady  Co Ultimate Aqua Challenge,.Conaill McGrady, director of M B McGrady  Co, said: ldquoWe are delighted to be supporting Air Ambulance NI for a second year and helping to contribute to maintaining the vital work that they do. Last year we held the first Aqua Challenge and this year we wanted to do another first ndash so Bubbles and Beer came to fruition.ldquoJust like last year we are encouraging not only clients, co-workers and friends to take part, but also those within the local community who are looking for a fun challenge.Mr McGrady paid tribute to Ed Lindsay and his team at Finnebrogue Woods, which he described as a stunning location.He added: ldquoWe are working with local event management company,  Extreme, to ensure this is an enjoyable and memorable experience for all involved and encourage people of all abilities to come down and enjoy a walk or run.Air Ambulance NI Area Fundraising Manager, Grace Williams, said: ldquoWe are very proud that M B McGrady  Co are continuing to support Air Ambulance NI with another unique, fun, family event.ldquoItrsquos set to be a great evening and we would love to get as many people as possible taking part, enjoying the evening and raising money for our charity.She added: The Helicopter Emergency Medical Serviceis tasked on average at least once a day. To ensure this is sustained, we need to raise pound million each year so public support is crucial. By taking part yoursquoll be making a lesaving dference and helping to raise vital funds for Air Ambulance NI.Air Ambulance NI works in partnership with the Northern Ireland Ambulance Service to provide the Helicopter Emergency Medical Service for Northern Ireland and is the local accountancy firmrsquos charity partner of choice for the second year.M B McGrady  Co Chartered Accounts has three offices situated in Downpatrick, Belfast and Newtownards.The race starts at .pm, with registration open from .pm. To sign up visit www.mbmcgrady.eventbrite or call   ..prettyPhoto

title: Classy Corey lifts silver at World Youth Savate event
story: AN Annacloy teenager has just ed home from from the Savate World Youth Championships in Budapest with a silver medal.Thirteen year-old Corey McCullough, a member of Joe Ferrisrsquo Bryansford Academy, who was at the championships as part of the Irish team, narrowly missed out on gold to a Russian fighter he had beaten earlier in the competition.Savate, a French combat sport that uses the hands and feet as weapons, combining elements of English boxing with graceful kicking techniques, has been an integral part of Coreyrsquos le for the past three years mdash although he has been kick boxing since he was six.Corey fought in the kg category and he has now set his sights on being part of the Ireland team that will travel to the European Championships next year.A pupil at St Malachyrsquos High School, Castlewellan, Corey is indebted to his coaches Joseph Ferris and Martin OrsquoMalley. He is also extremely grateful to sponsor Philip Polly, from CosyRoof and Brian McElroy, of Premier Chiropractic Centre, Downpatrick..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick FC host Golf Day
story: THE clubrsquos annual Golf Day was held last Friday at St Patrickrsquos Golf Club, with over  players playing on a course which was in pristine condition and in glorious sunshine.Unfortunately, nobody was able to take advantage of the playing conditions and get a hole in one at the par three th and secure pound, in cash which was kindly sponsored by Murphyrsquos Bar and Restaurant.The winners were: membersrsquo first prize, Michael Baggley nd Conor McMenamin rd, Mark Fitzsimons. The non-membersrsquo winners were: st Andy Baggley and nd Joe McMahon. The closest to the pin on th was Mark Murphy.The club would like to thank Murphyrsquos Bar  Restaurant for sponsoring the hole-in-one, thank you to Docrsquos Fish  Chip Shops for sponsoring the BBQ and to all our hole sponsors: Niall Powderly and family, Sean McMahon, Connollyrsquos Spar, BMD Contracts, Molloyrsquos Fish  Chip Shop, Bayview Killough Holiday Home, McGreevyrsquos Butchers, Eugene Milligan, MC Dental Laboratory, ALPS, United Mortgages, JRrsquos of Castlewellan, Matts Gardening Service and The : Diet, Down, Lecale  Ards. We would also like to say a special thanks to St Patrickrsquos Golf Club captain Patrick Totton, the members of St Patrickrsquos Golf Club, club professional Charlie Bell and the excellent greenkeepers for allowing us to use their excellent facility.Downpatrick begin their league campaign in Division A tomorrow night with an away fixture against Orangefield OB at Cregagh Sports Club in Belfast. This match kicks off at .pm. Then on Tuesday night they travel to play Rosario YC at Ulidia Playing Fields, this match kicks off at .pm.Over the next few weeks all our teams will be ing to training in preparation for the upcoming season, keep an eye on our Social Media pages for more information..prettyPhoto

title: Fred seals win in added time
story: A FREDDIE OrsquoConnor point in added time gave Bright a stirring victory over second-placed St Paulrsquos at Pairc Mac Con Midhe on Friday night.The game was played in perfect conditions with a slight sea breeze being the only element for players to contend with.Bright took possession from the throw-in and ultimately controlled the early part of the game. They opened the scoring through Gareth George and he added a free to give the visitors an early cushion.Indeed, Bright had plenty more chances to add to this score, but were wasteful in their shot selection. The Holywood men finally woke up and a tidy score from Connor McAnespie after  minutes opened their account.Bright again replied with a fine score from Marc Burke before Martin Cox opened his account for Holywood with a point after  minutes. Barry Kilkey levelled the contest three minutes later from close range and Freddie OrsquoConnor scored for Bright to edge them ahead again.Foolish tackling and unnecessary frees were costing St Paulrsquos in the game and helped Bright dominate the play In the first half.The gamersquos opening goal, however, swung the play towards the Holywood men again. Fantastic work from Seaacuten Tucker around the middle of the park and his long ball into the danger area found Marty Cox in space.Cox caught the ball in mid-air, landed and turned in one motion before smashing the ball past Michael Ferrand, who had no chance. The sizable crowd roared with delight and momentum was now with St Paulrsquos as Tucker added another score from play.Once again, however, ill discipline and poor tackling would cost St Paulrsquos. Paddy Falls high tackle left George with a handy free to cut the deficit before Tucker added a free from m out on the left.George added the final score of the half for Bright leaving St Paulrsquos two points clear at the half-time whistle - to -.Bright again took the early initiative at the start of the second half and a point by Rian Tempany set the early tone. A big talking point came at six minutes into the second half when referee John McMullan sent off two players, one from each team after an altercation at a break downThe next few scores were to and fro with Tucker scoring three points and George replying in kind, aided by Tempany. The game was tied at - to - drawing at  when St Paulrsquosadded their second goal in the th minute.Fine work from Daniel Eastwood and Cox set up Tucker who danced around two Bright defenders before slotting the ball home from  metres. The home crowd were again in raptures, expecting St Paulrsquos to see the game out.However, game management has been a big problem this season for the Holywood men, given the average age of the team is  it is perhaps understandable that experience to see games out is just not there yet.St Paulrsquos tried to slow the game down, but with about  minutes still to be played, it was far too early for that. Bright caught St Paulrsquos in possession on numerous occasionsand turned the ball over for score after score.George was a constant threat and punished each mistake by the Holywood men with a score. Ably assisted by Freddie OrsquoConnor, the pair hauled the St Paulrsquos lead in until it was all square by the th minute.They again caught St Paulrsquos out and OrsquoConnor scored the winning point in the st minute.St Paulrsquos: Craig McKenna, Owen Loughran, Conor McPeake, Ryan Loughran, Ruairi Collins, Paddy Falls, Michael Collins , Gerard Walls, Patrick Eastwood, Martin Cox , Seaacuten Tucker , Daniel Eastwood, Barry Kilkey , Conor McAnespie . Subs: Daacuteire McGrattan. Ryan Hughes, Conleth Rooney, Rodney Adams, Colm OrsquoConnor, Matthew Crozier, Josh Johnston, Fintan Eastwood, Euan Morrow.Bright: Michael Farrand, Niall Byrne, Barry Mageean, Noel Travers, Corey Ranaghan, Nicholas OrsquoConnor, Freddie OrsquoConnor , Cailean Toner, Seamas Tumelty, Jack McLaughlin, Declan Trainor , Gareth George , Marc Burke , Kevin Groves , Owen McEvoy. Subs: Martin Murphy, Oran Tumelty, Christopher Byrne, James Hanna, Joseph Farrand, Rian Tempany , Declan Quinn, Jude McCrissican.St Paulrsquos -Bright -ACFL DIVISION .prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C July 31%2C 1979
story: DOWNPATRICK mdash Downpatrick is believed to have been put under the microscope for possible inclusion in the itinerary for the Popersquos three-day visit to Ireland.The programme for the Popersquos visit has already been drawn up and dispatched to Rome, but no one is willing to confirm that Downpatrick is on the list.The Primate, Cardinal Thomas OrsquoFiaich, was unavailable for comment, but a spokesman for him said that he could not comment on the matter. He did, however, admit that the itinerary has been sent to Rome.Venues for the Popersquos visit are pure speculation and certainly newspapers are free to speculate, he added.It is understood that Downpatrick was one of the three venues north of the border suggested by the committee of  bishops, headed by Cardinal OrsquoFiaich, when they met last week.The decision on whether the Pope will include Northern Ireland in his tour will be taken in Rome, but it is believed that alternative venues in the Republic have been suggestedthe Pope decides not to cross the border.The choice of Downpatrick mdash with its strong historical links with Christianity and St Patrick mdash is understood to have been a move to give the Pope the opportunity to see as many people as possible.It is also thought that Armagh mdash the ecclesiastical headquarters of the Roman Catholic Church in Ireland mdash and Londonderry were studied as possible venues for a visit.Until the programme is finalised, the only places certain to be included in the itinerary are Dublin and the Marian Shrine at Knock, County Mayo.Dr Joseph Maguire, Parish Priest of Downpatrick, said that he personally had not been contacted about any visit from Pope John Paul II, but he admitted that Downpatrick would have been one of the first places to think of.ldquoWe would be delighted to be so honoured with a visit from the Holy Father and he would be most welcome he said.KILLYLEAGH mdash A one-day token strike by production workers closed the Killyleagh Mill yesterday.Around  workers walked out, seeking a wages increase. It is understood that negotiations are going on around the table to try and thrash out a compromise.The token strike, which is also hitting other linen firms in the province, is expected to be prolonged unless the workers receive what they are seeking.TYRELLA mdash An extensive redevelopment of Tyrella Beach has been earmarked in a draft report which proposes to bring most of the beach area into public ownership.The report prepared by a group of consultant engineers working for the Down District Council has been described as ldquohighly practical and has already been given council approval.No cost estimates have yet been carried out on the scheme, but senior council officials are already preparing the way to convince the Department of Commerce and the Northern Ireland Tourist board to supply the necessary money.If the plan goes ahead the biggest change in the appearance of Tyrella will be the absence of cars on the beach area. Two special zones will be developed for car parking on either side of the beach and a park for upwards of  cars will be provided in the centre, off the beach area.Under no circumstances, however, will cars be allowed to drive up and down the beach area and the council is expected to appoint full-time beach inspectors to supervise parking during the summer season.The private entrances presently used by beach-goers will be blocked off and two new public driveways will be constructed. It is thought that charges for cars to the beach will be scrapped.Other developments at the beach will include the provision of new toilet blocks and the construction of - self-catering holiday homes for renting.NEWCASTLE mdash A new peal of six church bells will ring out over Newcastle this year. They will be installed in St Johnrsquos Parish Church, which will be  years old in .Dr Noel Warren, the rector, says the parishioners are looking forward with tremendous interest to hearing the first peal of new bells to be installed in any church in Ireland for many years. The installation scheme will cost pound,, of which pound, has already been raised.The only special event to raise money has been a coffee party by Mr and Mrs Gerald Annesley. It produced about pound,.The church has always been under the patronage of the Annesley family who paid a great deal of its construction cost.STRANGFORD mdash The Roads Division has confirmed the report in the Recorder last week that the Cranglersquos Rock Corner, near Strangford, is to be re-aligned mdash and they have announced a firm starting date.A spokesman admitted this week that work had already started but he explained that this was only preliminary to the actual scheme to re-align the three bends, and was being carried out with the consent of local landowners.The spokesman also admitted that the scheme had been brought forward from its original starting date of - because of pressure from district councillors and local people.ARDGLASS mdash The death took place on Monday of one of the most popular persons in the area, William Curran, of Ardglass. Sailor Bill , as he was known, was born in Blaneystown and was a nephew of that other great Sheepland character, Willrsquos Billy Curran.In , Sailor joined the Royal Navy and his -year hitch took him through the first World War and some time in the West Indies.When he retired from the navy he became restless at home and decided he would give the minefields in Scotland a try.After his first day down in Ayrshire pit he was very disillusioned and decided not tobut he was prevailed upon to give it at least another day. He did and this day turned into  years.CROSSGAR mdash Crossgar man David McClurg continued on his winning ways with his Jersey cows at the County Antrim Agricultural Show at Antrim on Saturday.Having won the championship at Omagh and Castlewellan Shows, he made it a hat-trick of successes.Not only did he win the Granger Cup for the champion Jersey, but also the Lever Cup for the champion heer, the Lawther Cup for the best group and the first winner of the Eagle Cup for the Jersey with the best udder.KILLOUGH mdash A nephew of the late Canon Napier, of Killough, has been conferred the honour of Knighthood of St Gregory by Pope John Paul II. Dr S Napier, who has been in practice in Derby, for the last  years, received the honour recently.TEMPLE mdash Banbridgersquos Noel Hudson became the latest name to enter the Temple  record books when he won two races on Saturday.But it was Dromara Destroyer Ray McCullough, who caught the eye of the locals as he won the cc class to chalk up his th first place over the Temple course since first racing there  years ago.Many doubted McCulloughrsquos ability to win at the temple on Saturday. Since his spectacular fallin the North West last year, he hasnrsquot been registering victories as often mdash but they reckoned without his love for the Temple course and watched eagerly as he ran up another success.GAA mdash Loughinisland for so long known as the lsquogypsiesrsquo of East Down football, as far as playing pitches is concerned, have at last come of age.On Sunday their new ground and permanent home will be officially opened by Paddy McFlynn, the president of the GAA.The Loughinisland club was founded at the start of the present century and in their  years they have, at ious times, played on pitches throughout theand breadth of the parish..prettyPhoto

title: Full steam ahead for dinosaur adventures
story: THE Downpatrick and County Down Railwayrsquos programme of summer events got underway last week to a lsquoroaringrsquo success.The Jurassic Express was the first big event of the railwayrsquos exciting summer programme and was more successful than they could possibly have imagined.Railway chairman Robert Gardiner said: ldquoWho knew dinosaurs and railways went together ldquoWe had baby dinos and their keepers on the train, and when the train got to Inch Abbey the passengers disembarked and walked down to our picnic area where lsquoRoaryrsquo the T-Rex was waiting for them.He added: ldquoEven though you know they are puppets, itrsquos still quite unsettling when Roary the T-Rex charges at you.ldquoWe carried over  dino-fans on five packed-out trains throughout the day, with people travelling as far as Dublin.Visitor Jen Banks said: ldquoIt was fantastic, my son Lorcaacuten was beside himself and daughter Sarola was terried. The train is lovely and all the volunteers made it so special. Fab time.Lee Monahan commented: ldquoAnother great day thanks again guys.Lynsey Smyth said: ldquoWas a great day. My wee boy Olly had a ball.Elaine McMillan said: ldquoWe had a great day. Think I was worse than the kids for enjoying it.Ranger Claire Johnston, from Jurassic Hire, said: ldquoWe had so much fun on the day. We love what we do and enjoy it as much as the kids,not more.ldquoWhilst researching my daughterrsquos dinosaur-themed party, I realised that Northern Ireland was lacking le size T-Rex dinosaurs to hire.ldquoI decided I would take a leap of faith and jump into the crazy world of family entertainment. I havenrsquot looked back. I love what I do. I love seeing the expressions on peoplersquos faces when they see a full size dinosaur.Mr Gardiner said the programme of special events, supported by Newry Mourne  Down Council, continues throughout the summer months.ldquoOur next one is the lsquoSuperTrainrsquo on August  where the Avengers battle the evil Red Skull to stop the demise of the Downpatrick  County Down Railway from happening as he plans to turn all the steam trains into dirty diesels.This August also sees the start of some events for the grown-ups at the DCDR, with the first of these events giving wine-lovers a chance to enjoy some Hungarian wines with the lsquoWhistle and Winersquo steam trains this Saturday and the lsquoGin Expressrsquo on August .A full list of events can be found online at www.downrail..prettyPhoto

title: Kodi (11) to be laid to rest
story: BRAVE little Kodi Brown from Killinchy will be buried tomorrow after a year-long fight against a brain tumour.The  year-old died last Tuesday in the arms of her mother and surrounded by her family after receiving pioneering medical treatment in Germany.More than pound, was raised by local supporters and well-wishers to fund the specialised treatment which was not available in the UK.Her funeral service will be held in St Maryrsquos Parish Church, Kilmood, and will be followed by interment in the adjoining graveyard.Kodirsquos mother, Gemma, announced the tragic news on Kodirsquos Krew fundraising Facebook page last week, saying: ldquoThe most beautul soul is now free from the most brutal disease.Mrs Brown said she was ldquoblessed and honoured to have been her mum and that her ldquoprecious little girl was not only my daughter but one of the best friends I have ever had.ldquoThe light, the joy and the motivation she brought into my le and to so many others will leave an agonising void, continued Mrs Brown.ldquoShe made me proud in abundance. Her ability to converse with people of all ages was remarkable. Quick-witted and vivacious, she could captivate her audiences with compelling stories of her own experiences and those from her dazzling imagination.ldquoHer mothering compassionate nature led her to help those troubled or in need and she was often courageous in doing so, especially with being so sensitive herself.Mrs Brown added that her family and the local community had lost ldquoa little hero and spoke of her daughterrsquos ability to love.ldquoIf Kodi loved you, you knew. She expressed her love openly to her family and friends daily, which is a quality I deeply admired and in her last weeks she used all her strength to tell us.Mrs Brown, who was with Kodi constantly during her treatment in Germany, spoke of her pain at losing her eldest child and only daughter.ldquoThe overwhelming pain I feel from losing the greatest gt of a daughter and to no longer be able to help her achieve her dreams, aspirations and all the special milestones I expected to experience with her will haunt me each day until I am called to be her mummy again.ldquoFor now, my darling son and I must find a way to live on through the pain. The power of love mdash we are forever broken.Kodi took ill last February during her P year at Killinchy Primary School while playing at a friendrsquos house. Initially diagnosed with a viral infection, she continued to take seizures at home.In May after a routine MRI, her family were told that there was still swelling on her brain. Four weeks later, the worst news that Kodi had a brain tumour was confirmed and there were no curative treatments available.Her family refused to give up hope and took Kodi to Germany on a self-funded trip where pioneering immunotherapy was offered, alongside infusion treatments.However, the costs of the treatment were prohibitive and Gemmarsquos friends created the Kodirsquos Krew fundraising appeal to fund the treatment and living costs.The Killinchy community and her school backed the fundraising effort with local events being held weekly.Killinchy Primary School principal Chris Currie last night spoke of losing Kodi ldquowho was loved by everyone.ldquoThe whole school community is devastated at Kodirsquos loss, he said. ldquoShe was very much a bright light. She was just so brave. The strength and maturity it took to go through what she did as such a young child was so impressive to us all.ldquoKodi will be massively missed and we will remember and celebrate her positivity as she was always up for a laugh and a bit of banter.Mr Currie said that the school threw itself as a community into the fundraising effort as well as supporting the family, particularly her brother Blake who also attends the school.ldquoWhen something like this happens to a child whorsquos one of our own, we give everything to do and have done our best to stand with the family and support them, he added.ldquoOur job now is to help the family deal with the aftermath and we will support the parents and Blake with whatever support we can give.Mr Currie said that he was overwhelmed by Kodirsquos maturity when she addressed a special school assembly in May and paid her thanks to the pupilsrsquo parents for helping her family with the treatment costs.Kodi is survived by her mother, Gemma, dad Andy, brother Blake, grandparents and extended family circle..prettyPhoto

title: Make a Wish is the winner
story: THE th Kevin Gorman Memorial Cup drew a massive crowd to Meadowvale, Drumaness, on Saturday.The annual fundraiser for the Make a Wish Foundation is run by Jackie and Shane Gorman mdash Kevinrsquos mother and brother mdash in memory of Kevin who tragically lost his le attempting to save a PSNI colleague in .Sixteen youth teams played in a tournament, before the main match which saw Drumaness Mills beating the PSNI - for the honour of the memorial cup in its last year.There was a number of attractions for the children throughout the family fun day, and the day concluded with music throughout the evening in the clubhouse.Jackie and Shane would like to thank everyone for their support throughout the years, including their loyal volunteers, sponsors, and Drumaness Mills for the use of their facilities.ldquoIt would be impossible to thank every inidual, but you know who you are and we extend our warmest and heartfelt thanks, Jackie said.ldquoIt was indeed fitting that the Mills won the cup in its final year, and this saw Kevinrsquos two daughters, Shannyn and Abi, present the cup to his brother, Shane..prettyPhoto

title: Pedestrian crossing required to address Newcastle safety issue
story: ROADS officials have been asked to consider providing a pedestrian crossing at Newcastlersquos South Promenade.The suggestion mdash to help improve driver and pedestrian safety at this busy part of the resort mdash was made recently by South Down MLA Colin McGrath during a meeting with Department for Infrastructure and Newry, Mourne and Down Council officials.The MLA said people who have to enter South Promenade have to contend with a busy traffic flow, with vehicles making their way to and from the Kilkeel direction.Mr McGrath continued: ldquoThis is a busy thoroughfare at all times of the day. As you leave the centre of Newcastle this particular road narrows and there are also a number of parked cars.ldquoUnfortunately, this high level of traffic has given rise to a number of speeding issues and there have been a number of collisions. Several years ago, a local man also lost his le in an accident at this part of the town.Mr McGrath explained that residents were keen to see a new crossing provided, suggesting that an ideal location would be at the bottom of Bath Lane.He explained: ldquoThis would allow pedestrians to cross the road in a safe manner but also form another connection between King Street and the Kilkeel Road. I have also contacted the local council to request the installation of a second pedestrian railing going down the steps at Bath Lane as a health and safety measure.Mr McGrath said it was important that roads and footpaths in the resort were safe, issuing an appeal to road users lower their speed and be mindful of their fellow road users..prettyPhoto

title: Saintfield director scoops accolades for 2:40 to London
story: HErsquoS done it again. A Saintfield writer and director has received more plaudits at a major British film festival.Gavin Irvine scooped Best Film and Best Comedy awards at the Brighton Rocks Film Festival for his hit comedy film, : to London.Gavin beat off stf competition with other entries in the comedy category alone.He said afterwards: ldquoI was shell-shocked when I heard my name being called out. I just canrsquot believe the run of good fortune Irsquom receiving.ldquoComedy is the hardest genre to be successful in. Probably becausecomedy is so subjective. You either get it or you donrsquot.The movie : to London has been described as a ldquoa wry Beckettian homage to the great British spy thriller but with carrots and beards.ldquoI suppose because the film is totally original, while it takes its influences from British Ealing comedy and the classic comedy era, it goes further with the idea of espionage and the spy thrillers mixed with some extremely dry wit, he remarked.ldquoThe comedy has been doing the short film festival circuit in London this year and the feedback has been amazing.ldquoMost notably, critics say the film is very original. For me, as a film-maker, lsquoploughing your own furrowrsquo is what itrsquos all about.ldquoI donrsquot want to be an imitator. I want to lead but, of course, this is extremely hard to do.Gavin is no stranger to the industryrsquos red carpet events with : to London having won the Audience Award at the Making Waves Film Festival in Portsmouth in  and Best Short Film at the German International Film Festival and the Brazil International Film Festival. It also received the Special Jury Award at the Canadian Independent Film Festival.Gavin, who fell into filming making over  years ago and was winning awards within two years. Earlier this year he scooped Best Short Screenplay for his latest film, Lunch, and the Rising Star Award for his debut music video, Rattling My Chains, at the Portuguese International Festival..prettyPhoto

title: Tributes paid to popular GP after motor racing accident
story: TRIBUTES have been paid to a Belfast GP who died in a crash at Kirkistown motor racing circuit on Saturday.Father-of-three, Dr Paul Conn , was a partner at a Belfast practice and had celebrated a win earlier in the day.An Air Ambulance was called to the scene following the accident but Dr Connrsquos le could not be saved. The rest of the meeting was abandoned.Observers say it was a ldquoracing accident which happened as Dr Conn attempted to overtake a slower car on the home straight.His sports car clipped the other car and was sent crashing off the track. Despite rapid response teams being available, Dr Conn was pronounced dead at the scene.Dr Conn had been a member of  Motor Racing Club Of Ireland for over  years and was described by them as a top racer who will be sorely missed.A spokesman for the club said: ldquoPaul was from Lisburn. He joined our club in  and during the intervening years he campaigned his lsquoCrossleacute Srsquo sports car with increasing success.ldquoIn  he seemed to reach a new level of skill and began to trouble the established top echelon of drivers in road sports, winning in the second race of the May meeting.Referring to Dr Connrsquos success on Saturday, he said: ldquoHe had already won the first road sports race, against top opposition, and he was on course for a repeat in the second race when he had an accident opposite the control tower.ldquoBecause of the location of the incident, our doctors and the Order Of Malta personnel were in attendance almost immediately, but unfortunately Paul succumbed to his injuries at the scene.ldquoOnce again, we offer our sincere condolences to Paulrsquos family, friends, colleagues and team. He will be sorely missed.Meanwhile in a statement, Motorsport UK said it was investigating the circumstances.A spokesman said: ldquoAs with all serious incidents in or around UK motor sport, Motorsport UK is now working with the event-organising club and the police to establish precisely what happened on this occasion.He added: ldquoMotorsport UK sends its sincere condolences to the family and friends of the deceased driver.A PSNI spokesman said it was ldquoinvestigating the circumstances surrounding the death of a man at a race track in Kircubbin on Saturday afternoon. A report will be prepared for the coroner.Jim Shannon MP for Strangford expressed his sympathy to Dr Connrsquos family.He said: ldquoThe tragedy that took the le of Dr Conn shocked all of those at the Belfast and District Motorsport Club and the wider sporting community.ldquoThe circuit at Kirkistown is a popular location for car, kart and motornike enthusiasts and it has in the past had three other fatalities, but this is the first one in a car.ldquoDr Conn had been a GP for almost all of this working le and this terrible accident has taken a family man and a wonderful GP from a community that is grieving his loss.He added: ldquoTo his family circle at this time, I know I speak for all in this community when I extend our heartfelt and sincere condolences and prayers at this time..prettyPhoto

title: Ursula’s special day at Spa
story: SPA lady president Ursula Kelly hosted the clubrsquos third major event of the season on Friday with her Lady Presidentrsquos Day competition mdash played in glorious sunshine on a course which continues to attract so much favourable comment.Once again it was Carol Shields who topped the leaderboard, continuing her outstanding season long success with a fantastic score of  points.Pam Trohear was also on top form, taking the gross prize while Gwyneth Cordner was second and Elaine Beattie was third.Philip Shields was the leading man in the nine-hole menrsquos competition after facing fierce competition from Pat Savage, who was second, and Graham Mills, who finished third.The lady president said that for her it had been ldquoa very special day and after congratulating all the winners, thanked everyone involved in the preparation and presentation of the event and all who had competed.She paid tribute to the ldquohard work and efficiency of handicap secretary Gillian Earls, ladysecretary Catherine McEvoy, lady captain LizGeddes and the ladiesrsquo committee along with Marian Armstrong and Heather Edgar in the office, juvenile convenor Gwyneth Cordner, professional Gary Wardlow, the bar, catering and grounds staff.ldquoI want to thank my family and extended family for the support they have given me over the past two years and especially my long suffering husband Jimmy. title: fermanagh peer calls mlas get back work
story: A Fermanagh peer has said people are ldquofed up to the teeth at the ongoing impasse at Stormont and called on MLAs here to get back to work.Viscount Brookeborough, The Queenrsquos Lord Lieutenant for County Fermanagh, told the House of Lords last week that ldquo per cent of people in Northern Ireland want a restoration of our devolved Parliament.ldquo per cent of the normal people in Northern Ireland are totally and absolutely frustrated by our political parties not getting together. We should forget who is to blame.ldquoThe people around us at home are fed up to the teeth with the politicians whom they elected to our Assembly being, for whatever reason, incapable of sorting something out for us, he said.Directing his remarks at his fellow peers, Viscount Brookeborough said: ldquoAlthough you are no longer Assembly Members, go back home and get your parties to agree.ldquoGet there, talk and produce a legitimate Government for us in Northern Ireland. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. Mr Wilson said that Mr Johnson should tell the taoiseach: “No, no, no.”Mr Varadkar made clear that Ireland is not prepared to renegotiate the backstop – the insurance policy which it insists is crucial to ensure an open border on the island of Ireland but which unionists have overwhelmingly opposed because it would erect barriers between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK.When askedno-deal was now the most likely outcome, Mr Varadkar said: “I think that as time goes on, it becomes more likely. I’m not sure at what point you say it becomes more than % likely or not – and I’m not sure what that necessarily achieves anyway because we’ve always been preparing for the possibility of no-deal, and been doing that for years now. “But I’m certain it can be avoided.”Mr Varadkar set out three means by which no-deal could be avoided: MPs ratying an agreement with the EU, an extension to again delay Brexit “which is an optionit is put forward for a good reason” or “ parliament and the government were to decide to – and it would have to be their decision it’s not my decision – to revoke article ”.He insisted that “ no-deal happens on October , it will be as a consequence of decision made in London, not one made in Brussels or Dublin”.The taoiseach said that he “would be very keen to over the course of the next few weeks to actually sit down with Prime Minister Johnson and talk through with him how we got to this point because I think there’s a bit of an effort now to make out that the Withdrawal Agreement, including the backstop, was an invention of the Dublin government or imposed by the European Union. That’s not the case.”He added: “What I’d like to do is talk through how we got to that point. Our analysis is dferent – we ended up with the Withdrawal Agreement and the backstopbecause of all the red lines that were drawn up by the British government. “Nowwe’re going back to square one and those red lines are being changed, then we’ve something to talk about.”Leo Varadkar: Stormont needs to be restored to give Northern Ireland a Brexit voice Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BELF | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BELF | Article Teaser"Theresa May’s key red lines were that the UK would leave the single market, would leave the customs union, would end free movement and would bring an end to the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice in Britain.However, playing down any hopes of even such a substantial sht by Mr Johnson leading to a sudden deal which would see the UK leave at the end of October, he said: “It’s very dficult to see how you could conclude a dferent agreement between now and October  when the last one took two years to negotiate.”Pressed on whether, even in the event of Mr Johnson changing the UK’s red lines there could be a deal by October , he said: “I think it becomes extremely dficult. But again, October st is a deadline that was agreed between the EU and the UK. “The European Union is saying thatthere’s a good reason we can do a further extension.”When askedhe knew what would happen at the Irish border on November the UK was to leave without a deal, Mr Varadkar said: “Well, I suppose that’s still something that we’re still trying to work out in our discussions with the European Commission.“What will certainly happen is thatthe UK leaves without a deal and reverts to the WTO rules, then yes, we will have to impose WTO rules ... that does involve tarfs on imports, both north-south and also east-west and it does involve businesses having to file customs forms and tax forms and so on.“And we’ll have to have some form of checks somewhere. Obviously we don’t want to have them on the border and our preference would be to have them at the ports of entry, at business level and random checks too.”When askedbusinesses could at least have certainty that any checks will not be able to be imposed immediately and therefore trade will not halt on November , Mr Varadkar did not directly answer the question.Pressed on when those checks would begin, he said: “If the UK decides to leave without a deal and reverts to WTO rules and leaves without a deal, it would happen immediately – that’s my understanding of the legal position anyway, and it’s not something that we want it’s something that we want to avoid.“Butthat’s the decision that’s made ... you’d have the tarf barriers, which is cost, and you’d have all the other non-tarf barriers to trade as they call them – having to fill in all the forms, having to pre-declare and so on.”He said that even a no-deal Brexit or a withdrawal agreement without the backstop would not bring certainty for businesses because it would be “just kicking the fundamental questions about the Irish border and about trade between the UK and Ireland into the implementation phase or the transition phase ... so you end up with another two or three years of business uncertainty and that’s not a desirable outcome”.Responding to the argument often made by many Brexiteers and unionists thatthe UK and Ireland agreed not to erect a hard border then that can be avoided, Mr Varadkar alluded to his country’s willingness to ensure that border checks take place, saying that “from our side we would have to uphold the integrity of the single market and the customs union”.He also said that “the idea that the UK could withdraw from the European Union, join the WTO and then the first thing the UK would do would be to break the WTO rules – it’s not a basis for a future trade policy or free trade agreements with anybody, really.”try catch  TrendingN.I. title: view from parliament stephen doughty
story: There is no getting around it we must call the result of the European election what it is ndash a huge wake up call for UK Labour and Welsh Labour.But the vote for those parties whoclearly oppose a reckless Tory No-Deal Brexit and are campaigning for a final say in a public vote, was incredibly strong.The Brexit Party and Faragersquos isive far right politics were not supported by around two-thirds of voters ndash and it is absolutely clear therefore that No Deal was rejected.But the truth is that the country remains ided, and the only way to resolve this is to go back to the British people in a confirmatory referendum.UK Labour must now back this policy clearly, and Irsquom pleased to see senior shadow cabinet members speaking out on this.I therefore also welcome the clarity from Welsh Labourrsquos First Minister Mark Drakeford who said: ldquoFaced with the damage of a hard line Tory Brexit, Welsh Labour believes that the final decision must be made by the public in a referendum."And for the avoidance of any doubt, a Welsh Labour Government would campaign, in such a vote, for Wales to remain in the EU."We will work with any others who seek the same outcome.It is easy to claim to know what the will of the people is ndash but the only way to find out is to actually ask them.This is what the hard line Brexiteers are afraid of.As poor as the European election results were for Labour, the Conservative vote completely collapsed, and their party is in absolute turmoil.With Theresa May announcing that she will depart soon, we are already seeing the posturing of Tory MPs who want to become their partyrsquos new leader and thereforethe Prime Minister.Any new Tory leader must realise two crucial facts: that there is NO majority in Parliament or in the country for a reckless No Deal Brexit ndash as the results of the European elections make clear and the ONLY way to resolve this chaos is to put the issue back to the people, and for the public to have a final say on how we move forward. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey title: an inspector calls andy rice
story: Their behaviour is intimidating and will not be tolerated in our community. Wersquove had reports of youths consuming alcohol, using nitrous oxide canisters along with reports of damage caused to motor vehicles.Officers are working with British Transport Police to tackle this issue.Alcohol has been confiscated from groups of youths and a number of anti-social behaviour referrals orders have been made.Patrols have increased around the anti-social behaviour hotspots and operations at the train stations and surrounding areas will continue.I would also like to raise awareness of rogue traders in the area.Last week, officers attended to an address after concerns were raised about an elderly woman being asked to pay a large sum of money to have her patio cleaned.No money was exchanged and enquiries are ongoing into this incident.Residents should be wary of anyone who arrives at their property unannounced and uninvited and they should always very callers are who they say they are.We would advise people not to allow cold callers access to their property, to get at least two separate quotes before agreeing to have any work being carried out, to look out for their elderly relatives and neighbours, be vigilant and to contact the police immediatelythey are approached by any suspicious iniduals.If you see something suspicious or have any information related to this activity then call us on  or on appropriate. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. story: Stephen Doughty MP" View from Westminster: Stephen Doughtyx" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentTHIS week Irsquove been speaking out against the ill-judged state visit of Donald Trump, a President that I believe is racist, sexist, isive and a liar.He says itrsquos fine to lsquograb womenrsquo sexually he has offended the LGBT community he wanted to ban all Muslims from entering the United States he used derogatory and offensive language about African countries he has supported far right organisations in the US and here in the UK the list goes on.We should of course be having government to government contact, but this is about drawing lines ndash and I think it is wrong that we have chosen to honour him in this way.It was grossly naiumlve of the PM to have offered this visit in the first place - many American Presidents have not been offered a state visit, we didnrsquot have to do it.We can have that governmental and diplomatic contact and we absolutely should be standing alongside America in NATO and in so many other ways - but for Trump the red carpet has been rolled out despite him being so offensive to civilised values.We choose who we honour and I think itrsquos appalling that we are welcoming with such pomp a man who I think represents the very worst of the world ndash and certainly doesnrsquot represent the British and American values that I love.Last Friday I helped to host a group discussion that attempted to bring together all sides of the Brexit debate - despite having lost my voice towards the end of last week!At the event, local people, employers, community leaders and young people ndash from both sides of the Brexit debate ndash gathered to discuss the biggest challenges that face this country.Rather than the endless arguments over whether or not we should leave the EU, the aim was to start thinking about how we can heal the isions in our country and put the focus back on all the other issues that really matter, such as ensuring we tackle crime, invest in our public services and act on global challenges like climate change.That begins with understanding why so many people voted to Leave in  and how we can tackle some of those issues. My own view on moving forward is that a final say Peoplersquos Vote on any Brexit deal is the best option.It was a really positive event, and thank you to all constituents who attended. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: penarth developments could lead to  more cars daily
story: The Barry to Cardf Link Road Group has said the number of planning applications already approved in the area - as well as a number still in the pipeline - will have a dramatic impact on traffic.The group has claimed the only alternative would bethe Welsh Government complete the Barry to Cardf link road with access into adjoining communities, saying this would improve access for Wimpy Homes Cog estate, which already has planning permission for  houses, with another  houses also planned.The Welsh Government itself owns the land overlooking the sea at Cosmeston, where  houses are planned.There are a further  houses to be built near Oak Court in Lower Penarth.Rod Harrod, the chairman of the Barry to Cardf Link Road Group, said: ldquoGovernment statistics estimate there are . cars per house so with , houses there could be over , more car journeys daily in the area.With most people travelling back and forth in the same day, conservatively traffic on the Penarth to Sully to Merrie Harrier roadcould rise by around , more trips every day.ldquoThese figures are not scare stories. The current congestion is there to be seen.ldquoAny changes will take at least five years to implement.ldquoEven without the extra  Wimpy homes there are already  new homes built at St Josephs on Sully Road and  planned for Llandough.ldquoThey will all converge on the Merrie Harrier junction.A study carried out in  - before most of the new developments were planned - predicted the junction would be  per cent over capacity by .The new Link Road group has been formed to engage with representatives of all surrounding areas.Cllr Neil Moore, leader of the Vale of Glamorgan Council, said: ldquoThe councilrsquos cabinet recently agreed to consider undertaking further work on the WelTAG Stage  assessment for improving strategic transport in Dinas Powys. Unfortunately, the recent Welsh Government Transport grant funding announcement for   did not make any monies available for this particular project. Therefore my officers are currently investigating whether there are any alternative sources of funding available to complete this Stage  work.Mr Harrod said: ldquoThis should be something for all the people of all the Eastern Vale.ldquoEach area should have its own group.ldquoWersquore asking councillors and officials to consider the domino benefits and detriments of the several routes proposed ndash not just one."He also emphasised that no particular route for a new relief road was preferred, saying: ldquoIt will inevitably require compromise.ldquoBut we want to make sure the final choice will stand firm when the Welsh Government assess the application. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... story: The Barry to Cardf Link Road Group has said the number of planning applications already approved in the area - as well as a number still in the pipeline - will have a dramatic impact on traffic.The group has claimed the only alternative would bethe Welsh Government complete the Barry to Cardf link road with access into adjoining communities, saying this would improve access for Wimpy Homes Cog estate, which already has planning permission for  houses, with another  houses also planned.The Welsh Government itself owns the land overlooking the sea at Cosmeston, where  houses are planned.There are a further  houses to be built near Oak Court in Lower Penarth.Rod Harrod, the chairman of the Barry to Cardf Link Road Group, said: ldquoGovernment statistics estimate there are . cars per house so with , houses there could be over , more car journeys daily in the area.With most people travelling back and forth in the same day, conservatively traffic on the Penarth to Sully to Merrie Harrier roadcould rise by around , more trips every day.ldquoThese figures are not scare stories. The current congestion is there to be seen.ldquoAny changes will take at least five years to implement.ldquoEven without the extra  Wimpy homes there are already  new homes built at St Josephs on Sully Road and  planned for Llandough.ldquoThey will all converge on the Merrie Harrier junction.A study carried out in  - before most of the new developments were planned - predicted the junction would be  per cent over capacity by .The new Link Road group has been formed to engage with representatives of all surrounding areas.Cllr Neil Moore, leader of the Vale of Glamorgan Council, said: ldquoThe councilrsquos cabinet recently agreed to consider undertaking further work on the WelTAG Stage  assessment for improving strategic transport in Dinas Powys. title: radio glamorgan studio renamed in honour of penarth volunteer
story: John Wilce worked in hospital radio from  until his death in September last ltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtyearlt spangtlt spangt" Radio studio renamed in honour of Penarth volunteerThe Radio Glamorgan team based out of University Hospital Wales, at the rededicaltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgttionlt spangtlt spangt" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentTHE studio at Hospital Radio Glamorgan has been renamed in memory of a dedicated Penarth volunteer.John Wilce joined the station based at the University Hospital of Wales in Cardf in  but sadly passed away after a short illness in September last year.Jamie Pritchard, Radio Glamorgan chairman, said: ldquoSince Johnrsquos passing, we have been thinking of ways of how we could honour him and his legacy at the station for many years to come. The renaming of our on-air studio to ldquoThe John Wilce Studio was a popular choice to recognise his outstanding dedication.ldquoJune  wouldrsquove been Johnrsquos th birthday, so this we felt really was a fitting tribute and a lovely memorial to all those who knew him, as a constant reminder of his contribution to Radio Glamorgan.Mr Wilce regularly presented on Sunday evenings, often dedicating features to listeners. Without fail he played a Beatles track every time he was on air.When Mr Wilce was off-air, he oversaw and maintained broadcast equipment, actively engaged in fundraising and stood as a trustee, assisting with the day-to-day running of the station.Jamie added: ldquoI speak on behalf of everyone at RG to say it was a privilege to know John, not only as a fellow volunteer but as a friend. He always put everyone  first and his patience was beyond words. His music knowledge was phenomenal and the impact he had on everyone he met, not just at Radio Glamorgan has really come to light since his passing.Michelle Fowler, volunteer services manager at Cardf and Vale University Health Board, said: ldquoItrsquos such a wonderful tribute to rename the studio after John. He really made an impact on our wards and with our patients who listened to his shows.ldquoItrsquos such a lovely way to mark not only Johnrsquos birthday but also to mark the contribution he made as a volunteer during Volunteersrsquo Week. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: youngsters celebrate in style as school marks world book day
story: The classes moved around the school and park, stopping at dferent locations to hear dferent storytellers ndash family, governors and friends of the school, many in full costume.Shelley Barrett was dressed as Mole from the Wind in the Willows. She said: ldquoI loved it. The children love being read to and I love doing the voices! I look forward to it every year, choosing the book and costume.Author Elly Grfiths read extracts from her new book lsquoA Girl Called Justicersquo, and shared insights about writing a story.At the end of the day, on Thursday, May , the children and parents were able to buy books from two pop-up book stalls on the playgrounds, organised by Grfin Books.The Albert Road media monitors said: "A big thank you to Mel and her team for helping us and the book stalls proved to be a big hit with everyone."It was a glorious day and the sun truly shone for all the children and adults who participated in this event."World Book Day has really inspired the children to get creative, have a go at writing their own stories and also read new books"Albert Primary School would like to say a big thank you to everybody who helped make the day such an overwhelming success!"On Thursday, May , Albert Primary celebrated World Book Day at school and across the road in Belle Vue Park, Penarth.The classes made their way around the school and Belle Vue Park, stopping at dferent locations to hear stories told by a number of dferent storytellers.The storytellers were made up of parents, governors, grandparents and friends of the school.The children listened to a iety of stories, some in Welsh, and with many of the storytellers in full costume.Shelley Barrett was dressed as Mole from the Wind in the Willows. I was inspired to read Wind in the Willows as the Shelley Norton Stage Schoolis putting it on next month at The Talent Shack."Favourite stories included a dragon, Mary Poppins, an exciting adventure with Toad and some very marvellous medicine.The school managed to get author Elly Grfiths in for the day, working with the Year  and  children.She read extracts from her new book lsquoA Girl Called Justicersquo, and shared insights with the pupils about how to write a good story.At the end of the day, the children and parents were able to buy books from two pop up book stalls on the playgrounds, organised by Grfin Books. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: vale of glamorgan new leader speaks
story: Cllrs Neil Moore And Lis Burnett Taken By Ldr " Vale of Glamorgan: New leader speaksCllrs Neil Moore And Lis Burnett Taken By Ldr " Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentTHE new leader of Vale council has said he will refuse to ldquokowtow to those who shout the loudest and will not be rushed into deciding on controversial proposals such as parking charges.Cllr Neil Moore, who is leading a new Labour-led administration, says it is likely key decisions onproposed parking charges and the lsquoclosurersquo of Llancarfan Primary School will not be made until later this year. He has also cast doubt on the future of the proposed Dinas Powys bypass, and say he believes the Barry Incinerator will be required to draw up an environmental impact assessment ndash which campaigners have been calling for.Cllr Moore and the councilrsquos new deputy leader Lis Burnett gained control of the authority in May.Their priorities include balancing the councilrsquos budget and preserving vital services for the most vulnerable in the face of a need to make pound million of savings over the next two years, as well as regeneration and building more homes, and improving school buildings.Cllr Moore said: ldquoWersquore going to be open and transparent and be prepared to work with people. If there are issues we will try to work through those issues.ldquoSometimes we will have to make decisions that not everyone is going to be happy with.ldquoWe have to be honest with people. We have to say these are the facts and whether we like it or not we will have to do some things dferently or not at all.Cllr Burnett added. ldquoBut we have to be honest about the levels of pressure on local government.ldquoOur priority has to be services to the most vulnerable.The Labour-led coalition includes members of the former Conservative cabinet, which quit the party when former leader John Thomas was deposed as leader of the Vale Tories. The coalition also includes Llantwit First Independents.This is where the new leadership stands on the key issues facing the Vale:Parking chargesCllr Moore said new parking charges proposed by the previous administration, which included town centre car parks, coastal resorts and country parks, will be reviewed.He said new parking charges are likely in the Vale, but they will be ldquorealistic.Cllr Moore said: ldquoWe have to be sensible. Some of the things put forward previously were off the wall, they went too far.ldquoIt will be a full revamp of everything. Whatever we do wersquore not going to fleece the residents of the Vale.ldquoWe may have to make some changes. It does cost money to provide car parking. There are things we will have to start charging for. It will be realistic and fair for everybody.School improvementsThe new cabinet says delivering on major new school buildings is a priority for the new administration.Developments in the pipeline include new builds forPencoedtre and Whitmore High Schools, and expansion and refurbishment of Ysgol Gymraeg Bro MorgannwgAgeing schools in the Vale are set to get a pound. million cash boost for repairs.Llancarfan Primary SchoolLlancarfan Primary School was set to be lsquoclosedrsquoand moved to a new pound million facility in Rhoose.The previous cabinet had approved the plans despite protests from parents and campaigners.Cllr Moore said Llancarfan School move was ldquopremature - but did not commit to scrapping the plan entirely.ldquoIf itrsquos justiable itrsquos justiable, he said. ldquoIf itrsquos not, we will look at alternatives.ldquoItrsquos not an easy decision to take. Itrsquos something we have to take some time about.ldquoWhat Irsquom not going to do is jump or kowtow to people who shout the loudest.Cllr Burnett has previously tweeted the closure of Llancarfan ldquowouldnrsquot be happeningLabour were running the council.New roadsWork continues on outline business cases for two major new roads being proposed ndash the A to M link around Pendoylan and Dinas Powys Bypass between Barry and Cardf ndash but no decision has been made whether either will actually go ahead.The future of both roads rests on whether Welsh Government and the council deem them viable, and whether ministers cough up the cash to fund them.But Cllr Moore said he doesnrsquot think Welsh Government will find the money required for the Dinas Powys Bypass.ldquoItrsquos out of our hands, he said.IncineratorCllr Moore said he believes Welsh Government will order the Barry Biomass incinerator to carry out an environmentalimpact assessment.Cllr Moore, who has previously attacked what he termed ldquoscaremongering and lies around the biomass plant, said he did not want the facility in Barry Docks.He said: ldquoWe opposed it vehemently, both as a council and as a party and personally. It shouldnrsquot be there.ldquoBut now it is there it has to operate within legal parameters.ldquoIf it does, therersquos nothing anyone can do about it.The council refused the original planning permission for the facility, but a planning inspector allowed it in  following an appeal. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: penarth car showroom to be redeveloped into moorwell apartments
story: The art deco car showroom on Windsor Road will soon be home to a collection of  one and two bedroom apartments and duplexes and a penthouse under a scheme named lsquoThe Moorwellrsquo.The creation of local developer Project Three Developments, The Moorwell will see the restoration and conversion of the former car showroom into contemporary homes set around a communal courtyard garden. Anytime Fitness Penarth gym will sit on the ground floor.Savills Cardf will start selling the homes at a price of pound, for a one-bedroom apartment.Built in the s by Stanley Sadler, the building was originally the premises of Sadler Bros Ltd, the successful car garage he ran with his brother, Aubrey Sadler. During the Second World War the building was used as an auxiliary workshop. It changed hands in the early s to become Moorwell Motors.Ben Wells, managing director at Project Three, said: ldquoWe are delighted to reveal our plans to restore and revitalise this impressive Penarth building.ldquoWe were immediately struck by the strong architectural style of the faccedilade and the light and space inside. It was clear there was potential to design a scheme that would honour the buildingrsquos character and heritage, while creating something new and contemporary for future generations to enjoy.Features include double height windows in the duplex and both private and communal outside spaces. A full floor penthouse has a roof terrace to the front and back with panoramic views.Dorothy Foulkes, daughter of Stanley Sadler, who designed and built the distinctive building and ran his business from there for many years, still lives in Penarth and recently visited the site of the development.She said: ldquoI have many memories of the garage over the years. Having stood empty for many years, I am delighted it is being given a new and exciting future. It is wonderful that the key features of the original beautully designed building are being preserved and transformed. It feels very appropriate, given my fatherrsquos very high standards and professionalism that The Moorwell is being designed and constructed with the same values. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: cardiff bus to hold hourly service to penarth on weekends
story: From June  until September , the bus operator will run an hourly service from Penarth Pier to the city centre on weekends and public holidays.The  service will run from Penarth Pier heading to Penarth town centre, Mermaid Quay and Wales Millennium Centre before reaching St Mary Street.Those wishing to take a day trip from Penarth to the city centre can take advantage of Cardf Busrsquos day and family travel tickets which offer affordable travel throughout Penarth and the capital.Adults with the Cardf Bus app can travel all day for pound., while young persons pay pound.. Families can also purchase a family day ticket for pound. on the app or from the driver, for either two adults and three children, or one adult and four children.Gareth Stevens, acting operations and commercial director at Cardf Bus, said: ldquoWe know that over the summer months, people like to get out and about locally so we put on this additional service to accommodate their needs.ldquoTherersquos a jam-packed schedule of exciting events taking place across the city and Penarthrsquos attractions and Pier mean itrsquos a popular place to take the family.ldquoThe regular service combined with our day and family tickets make it an affordable and convenient way to travel.ldquoWhether you are looking to visit the beach or explore the city this summer, Cardf Bus will get you there.For more information about bus travel, extra services, or tickets, please visit www.cardfbus or contact Cardf Bus via Twitter or Facebook. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice.
